answer: Microsoft is a leading technology company founded in 1975, headquartered in Redmond, Washington, known for its software products like Windows and Office. It has diversified into cloud computing, gaming, and AI. As of 2024, it employs over 228,000 people.

results.content:
Microsoft Corporation is an American multinational corporation and technology conglomerate headquartered in Redmond, Washington.( Founded in 1975, the company became influential in the rise of personal computers through software like Windows, and the company has since expanded to Internet services, cloud computing, video gaming and other fields. Microsoft is the largest software maker, one of the most valuable public U.S. companies,( and one of the most valuable brands globally. [...] Number of employees 228,000(2024)
Divisions "Division (business)")   Microsoft Gaming
   Microsoft 365
   Microsoft Research
   Windows and Devices Group
   Microsoft Cloud
   Microsoft AI
   Microsoft Security
   Microsoft Industry
   Microsoft Business Applications
   Microsoft Developer
Subsidiaries   GitHub
   LinkedIn [...] Microsoft has been market-dominant in the IBM PC–compatible operating system market and the office software suite market since the 1990s. Its best-known software products are the Windows line of operating systems and the Microsoft Office and Microsoft 365 suite of productivity applications, which most notably include the Word word processor, Excel spreadsheet editor, and the PowerPoint presentation program. Its flagship hardware products are the Surface lineup of personal computers and Xbox

**Microsoft Corporation** is an American [multinational corporation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multinational_corporation "Multinational corporation") and [technology conglomerate](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Technology_company "Technology company") headquartered in [Redmond, Washington](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Redmond,_Washington "Redmond, Washington").[[2]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-2) Founded in 1975, the company became influential in the [rise of personal computers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_personal_computers#The_early_1980s_and_home_computers "History of personal computers") through software like [Windows](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Windows "Windows"), and the company has since expanded to [Internet](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internet "Internet") services, [cloud computing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cloud_computing "Cloud computing"), [video gaming](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Video_gaming "Video gaming") and other fields. Microsoft is the [largest software maker](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_the_largest_software_companies "List of the largest software companies"), one of the [most valuable](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trillion-dollar_company "Trillion-dollar company") public U.S. companies,[[a]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-3) and one of the [most valuable brands](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_most_valuable_brands "List of most valuable brands") globally.

Microsoft was founded by [Bill Gates](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bill_Gates "Bill Gates") and [Paul Allen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paul_Allen "Paul Allen") to develop and sell [BASIC interpreters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BASIC_interpreter "BASIC interpreter") for the [Altair 8800](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Altair_8800 "Altair 8800"). It rose to dominate the personal computer operating system market with [MS-DOS](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MS-DOS "MS-DOS") in the mid-1980s, followed by Windows. During the 41 years from 1980 to 2021 Microsoft released 9 versions of [MS-DOS](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MS-DOS "MS-DOS") with a median frequency of 2 years, and 13 versions of Windows with a median frequency of 3 years. The company's 1986 [initial public offering](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Initial_public_offering "Initial public offering") (IPO) and subsequent rise in its share price created three billionaires and an estimated 12,000 millionaires among Microsoft employees. Since the 1990s, it has increasingly diversified from the operating system market. [Steve Ballmer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Steve_Ballmer "Steve Ballmer") replaced Gates as CEO in 2000. He oversaw the then-largest of [Microsoft's corporate acquisitions](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_mergers_and_acquisitions_by_Microsoft "List of mergers and acquisitions by Microsoft") in [Skype Technologies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Skype_Technologies "Skype Technologies") in 2011,[[3]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-4) and an increased focus on hardware[[4]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-5)[[5]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-6) that led to its first in-house PC line, the [Surface](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft_Surface "Microsoft Surface"), in 2012, and the formation of [Microsoft Mobile](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft_Mobile "Microsoft Mobile") through [Nokia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nokia "Nokia"). Since [Satya Nadella](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Satya_Nadella "Satya Nadella") took over as CEO in 2014, the company has changed focus towards [cloud computing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cloud_computing "Cloud computing"),[[6]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-7)[[7]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-8) as well as its large acquisition of [LinkedIn](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LinkedIn "LinkedIn") for $26.2 billion in 2016.[[8]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-9) Under Nadella's direction, the company has also expanded its video gaming business to support the [Xbox](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xbox "Xbox") brand, establishing the [Microsoft Gaming](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft_Gaming "Microsoft Gaming") division in 2022 and [acquiring](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Acquisition_of_Activision_Blizzard_by_Microsoft "Acquisition of Activision Blizzard by Microsoft")[Activision Blizzard](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Activision_Blizzard "Activision Blizzard") for $68.7 billion in 2023.[[9]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-10)

Microsoft has been market-dominant in the [IBM PC–compatible](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IBM_PC%E2%80%93compatible "IBM PC–compatible") operating system market and the office software suite market since the 1990s. Its best-known software products are the Windows line of [operating systems](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Microsoft_operating_systems "List of Microsoft operating systems") and the [Microsoft Office](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft_Office "Microsoft Office") and [Microsoft 365](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft_365 "Microsoft 365") suite of productivity applications, which most notably include the [Word](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft_Word "Microsoft Word") word processor, [Excel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft_Excel "Microsoft Excel") spreadsheet editor, and the [PowerPoint](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft_PowerPoint "Microsoft PowerPoint") presentation program. Its flagship [hardware products](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Microsoft_hardware "List of Microsoft hardware") are the Surface lineup of personal computers and [Xbox](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xbox "Xbox") video game consoles, the latter of which includes the [Xbox network](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xbox_network "Xbox network"); the company also provides a range of consumer Internet services such as [Bing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft_Bing "Microsoft Bing") web search, the [MSN](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MSN "MSN") web portal, the [Outlook.com](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Outlook.com "Outlook.com") ([Hotmail](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hotmail "Hotmail")) email service and the [Microsoft Store](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft_Store "Microsoft Store"). In the enterprise and development fields, Microsoft most notably provides the [Azure](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft_Azure "Microsoft Azure")[cloud computing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cloud_computing "Cloud computing") platform, [Microsoft SQL Server](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft_SQL_Server "Microsoft SQL Server") database software, and [Visual Studio](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Visual_Studio "Visual Studio").[_[citation needed](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation\_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

Microsoft is considered one of the [Big Five](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Big_Tech "Big Tech") American [information technology](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Information_technology "Information technology") companies, alongside [Alphabet](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alphabet_Inc. "Alphabet Inc."),[[b]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-11)[Amazon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amazon_(company) "Amazon (company)"), [Apple](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Apple_Inc. "Apple Inc."), and [Meta](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Meta_Platforms "Meta Platforms").[[c]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-12) In April 2019, Microsoft reached a trillion-dollar [market cap](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Market_capitalization "Market capitalization"), becoming the third public U.S. company to be [valued at over $1 trillion](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trillion-dollar_company "Trillion-dollar company"). It [has been criticized](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Criticism_of_Microsoft "Criticism of Microsoft") for its monopolistic practices, and [the company's software](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Microsoft_software "List of Microsoft software") has been criticized for problems with [ease of use](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ease_of_use "Ease of use"), [robustness](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robustness_(computer_science) "Robustness (computer science)"), and [security](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computer_security "Computer security").

History
-------

Main article: [History of Microsoft](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_Microsoft "History of Microsoft")

For a chronological guide, see [Timeline of Microsoft](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_Microsoft "Timeline of Microsoft").

### 1972–1985: Founding

[![Image 13](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9b/Altair_8800_and_Model_33_ASR_Teletype.jpg/330px-Altair_8800_and_Model_33_ASR_Teletype.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Altair_8800_and_Model_33_ASR_Teletype.jpg)

An Altair 8800 computer (left) with the popular Model 33 ASR Teletype as terminal, paper tape reader, and paper tape punch

[![Image 14](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/4/4f/1981BillPaul.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:1981BillPaul.jpg)

[Paul Allen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paul_Allen "Paul Allen") and [Bill Gates](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bill_Gates "Bill Gates") on October 19, 1981, after signing a pivotal contract with [IBM](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IBM "IBM")[[10]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-Allan_2001-13): 228 

[![Image 15](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f1/Bill_Gates_and_Paul_Allen_Business_Cards.jpg/250px-Bill_Gates_and_Paul_Allen_Business_Cards.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Bill_Gates_and_Paul_Allen_Business_Cards.jpg)

Bill Gates and Paul Allen's Original Business Cards located in the Microsoft Visitor Center

Childhood friends [Bill Gates](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bill_Gates "Bill Gates") and [Paul Allen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paul_Allen "Paul Allen") sought to make a business using their skills in [computer programming](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computer_programming "Computer programming").[[11]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-14) In 1972, they founded [Traf-O-Data](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Traf-O-Data "Traf-O-Data"), which sold a rudimentary computer to track and analyze automobile traffic data. Gates enrolled at [Harvard University](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harvard_University "Harvard University") while Allen pursued a degree in computer science at [Washington State University](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Washington_State_University "Washington State University"), though he later dropped out to work at [Honeywell](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Honeywell "Honeywell").[[12]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-15)

The January 1975 issue of _[Popular Electronics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Popular\_Electronics "Popular Electronics")_ featured [Micro Instrumentation and Telemetry Systems](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Micro_Instrumentation_and_Telemetry_Systems "Micro Instrumentation and Telemetry Systems")'s (MITS) [Altair 8800](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Altair_8800 "Altair 8800") microcomputer,[[13]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-16) which inspired Allen to suggest that they could program a [BASIC](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BASIC "BASIC") interpreter for the device. Gates called MITS and claimed that he had a working interpreter, and MITS requested a demonstration. Allen worked on a simulator for the Altair while Gates developed the interpreter, and it worked flawlessly when they demonstrated it to MITS in March 1975 in [Albuquerque, New Mexico](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Albuquerque,_New_Mexico "Albuquerque, New Mexico"). MITS agreed to distribute it, marketing it as [Altair BASIC](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Altair_BASIC "Altair BASIC").[[10]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-Allan_2001-13): 108, 112–114  Gates and Allen established Microsoft on April 4, 1975, with Gates as CEO,[[14]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-BBCTL-17) and Allen suggested the name "Micro-Soft", short for micro-computer software.[[15]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-18)[[16]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-19) In August 1977, the company formed an agreement with ASCII Magazine in Japan, resulting in its first international office of [ASCII Microsoft](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ASCII_Corporation "ASCII Corporation").[[17]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-20) Microsoft moved its headquarters to [Bellevue, Washington](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bellevue,_Washington "Bellevue, Washington"), in January 1979.[[14]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-BBCTL-17)

Microsoft entered the [operating system](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Operating_system "Operating system") (OS) business in 1980 with its own version of [Unix](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unix "Unix") called [Xenix](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xenix "Xenix"),[[18]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-21) but it was [MS-DOS](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MS-DOS "MS-DOS") that solidified the company's dominance. [IBM](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IBM "IBM") awarded a contract to Microsoft in November 1980 to provide a version of the [CP/M](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CP/M "CP/M") OS to be used in the [IBM Personal Computer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IBM_Personal_Computer "IBM Personal Computer") (IBM PC).[[19]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-22) For this deal, Microsoft purchased a CP/M clone called [86-DOS](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/86-DOS "86-DOS") from [Seattle Computer Products](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle_Computer_Products "Seattle Computer Products") which it branded as MS-DOS, although IBM rebranded it to [IBM PC DOS](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IBM_PC_DOS "IBM PC DOS"). Microsoft retained ownership of MS-DOS following the release of the IBM PC in August 1981. IBM had copyrighted the IBM PC [BIOS](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BIOS "BIOS"), so other companies had to reverse engineer it for non-IBM hardware to run as [IBM PC compatibles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IBM_PC_compatible "IBM PC compatible"), but no such restriction applied to the operating systems. Microsoft eventually became the leading PC operating systems vendor.[[20]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-23)[[21]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-24): 210  The company expanded into new markets with the release of the [Microsoft Mouse](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft_Mouse "Microsoft Mouse") in 1983, as well as with a publishing division named [Microsoft Press](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft_Press "Microsoft Press").[[10]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-Allan_2001-13): 232  Paul Allen resigned from Microsoft in 1983 after developing [Hodgkin's lymphoma](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hodgkin%27s_lymphoma "Hodgkin's lymphoma").[[22]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-25) Allen claimed in _Idea Man: A Memoir by the co-founder of Microsoft_ that Gates wanted to dilute his share in the company when he was diagnosed with Hodgkin's disease because he did not think that he was working hard enough.[[23]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-26) Allen later invested in [low-tech](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Low_technology "Low technology") sectors, sports teams, commercial real estate, neuroscience, private space flight, and more.[[24]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-27)

### 1985–1994: Windows and Office

[![Image 16](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f4/Microsoft_Windows_1.0_pages2_3.jpg/250px-Microsoft_Windows_1.0_pages2_3.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Microsoft_Windows_1.0_pages2_3.jpg)

[Windows 1.0](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Windows_1.0 "Windows 1.0") was released on November 20, 1985, as the first version of the Windows line.

Microsoft released [Windows 1.0](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Windows_1.0 "Windows 1.0") on November 20, 1985, as a graphical extension for [MS-DOS](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MS-DOS "MS-DOS"),[[10]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-Allan_2001-13): 242–243, 246  despite having begun jointly developing [OS/2](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/OS/2 "OS/2") with IBM that August.[[25]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-28) Microsoft moved its headquarters from Bellevue to [Redmond, Washington](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Redmond,_Washington "Redmond, Washington"), on February 26, 1986, and went public with an [initial public offering](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Initial_public_offering "Initial public offering") (IPO) at the NASDAQ exchange on March 13,[[26]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-CBSCHRON-29) with the resulting rise in stock making an estimated four billionaires and 12,000 millionaires from Microsoft employees.[[27]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-30) Microsoft released its version of OS/2 to original equipment manufacturers (OEMs) on April 2, 1987.[[10]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-Allan_2001-13) In 1990, the Federal Trade Commission examined Microsoft for possible collusion due to the partnership with IBM, marking the beginning of more than a decade of legal clashes with the government.[[28]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-31): 243–244  Meanwhile, the company was at work on Microsoft [Windows NT](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Windows_NT "Windows NT"), which was heavily based on their copy of the OS/2 code. It shipped on July 21, 1993, with a new modular [kernel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kernel_(operating_system) "Kernel (operating system)") and the [32-bit](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/32-bit_computing "32-bit computing")[Win32 application programming interface](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Windows_API#Major_versions "Windows API") (API), making it easier to port from [16-bit](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/16-bit_computing "16-bit computing") (MS-DOS-based) Windows. Microsoft informed IBM of Windows NT, and the OS/2 partnership deteriorated.[[29]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-32)

In 1990, Microsoft introduced the [Microsoft Office](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft_Office "Microsoft Office") suite which bundled separate applications such as [Microsoft Word](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft_Word "Microsoft Word") and [Microsoft Excel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft_Excel "Microsoft Excel").[[10]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-Allan_2001-13): 301  On May 22, Microsoft launched [Windows 3.0](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Windows_3.0 "Windows 3.0"), featuring streamlined user interface graphics and improved protected mode capability for the [Intel 386](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/I386 "I386") processor,[[30]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-33) and both Office and Windows became dominant in their respective areas.[[31]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-34)[[32]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-35)

On July 27, 1994, the [Department of Justice's Antitrust Division](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Department_of_Justice_Antitrust_Division "United States Department of Justice Antitrust Division") filed a competitive impact statement that said: "Beginning in 1988 and continuing until July 15, 1994, Microsoft induced many [OEMs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Original_equipment_manufacturer "Original equipment manufacturer") to execute anti-competitive 'per processor licenses. Under a per-processor license, an OEM pays Microsoft a royalty for each computer it sells containing a particular microprocessor, whether the OEM sells the computer with a Microsoft operating system or a non-Microsoft operating system. In effect, the royalty payment to Microsoft when no Microsoft product is being used acts as a penalty, or tax, on the OEM's use of a competing PC operating system. Since 1988, Microsoft's use of per processor licenses has increased."[[33]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-36)

### 1995–2007: Foray into the Web, Windows 95, Windows XP, and Xbox

[![Image 17](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e9/300lx.jpg/250px-300lx.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:300lx.jpg)

In 1996, Microsoft released [Windows CE](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Windows_Embedded_Compact#History "Windows Embedded Compact"), a version of the operating system meant for personal digital assistants and other tiny computers, shown here on the [HP 300LX](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HP_300LX "HP 300LX").

Following Bill Gates's internal "Internet Tidal Wave memo" on May 26, 1995, Microsoft began to redefine its offerings and expand its product line into [computer networking](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computer_network "Computer network") and the [World Wide Web](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Wide_Web "World Wide Web").[[34]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-37) With a few exceptions of new companies, like [Netscape](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Netscape "Netscape"), Microsoft was the only major and established company that acted fast enough to be a part of the World Wide Web practically from the start. Other companies like [Borland](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Borland "Borland"), [WordPerfect](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WordPerfect "WordPerfect"), [Novell](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novell "Novell"), [IBM](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IBM "IBM") and [Lotus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lotus_Software "Lotus Software"), being much slower to adapt to the new situation, would give Microsoft market dominance.[[35]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-38)

The company released [Windows 95](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Windows_95 "Windows 95") on August 24, 1995, featuring [pre-emptive multitasking](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Preemption_(computing)#PREEMPTIVE "Preemption (computing)"), a completely new user interface with a novel [start button](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Start_menu "Start menu"), and 32-bit compatibility; similar to NT, it provided the Win32 API.[[36]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-39)[[37]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-40): 20  Windows 95 came bundled with the [online service](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Online_service_provider "Online service provider")[MSN](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MSN "MSN"), which was at first intended to be a competitor to the Internet,[_[dubious](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Accuracy\_dispute#Disputed\_statement "Wikipedia:Accuracy dispute") – [discuss](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Microsoft#Dubious "Talk:Microsoft")_] and (for OEMs) [Internet Explorer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internet_Explorer "Internet Explorer"), a [Web browser](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Web_browser "Web browser"). Internet Explorer was not bundled with the retail Windows 95 boxes, because the boxes were printed before the team finished the Web browser, and instead were included in the Windows 95 Plus! pack.[[38]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-41) Backed by a high-profile marketing campaign[[39]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-42) and what _[The New York Times](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The\_New\_York\_Times "The New York Times")_ called "the splashiest, most frenzied, most expensive introduction of a computer product in the industry's history,"[[40]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-43) Windows 95 quickly became a success.[[41]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-44) Branching out into new markets in 1996, Microsoft and [General Electric](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/General_Electric "General Electric")'s [NBC](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NBC "NBC") unit created a new [24/7](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/24/7_service "24/7 service") cable news channel, [MSNBC](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MSNBC "MSNBC").[[42]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-45) Microsoft created [Windows CE 1.0](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Windows_Embedded_Compact#Versions "Windows Embedded Compact"), a new OS designed for devices with low memory and other constraints, such as [personal digital assistants](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Personal_digital_assistant "Personal digital assistant").[[43]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-46) In October 1997, the Justice Department filed a motion in the Federal [District Court](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_district_court "United States district court"), stating that Microsoft violated an agreement signed in 1994 and asked the court to stop the bundling of [Internet Explorer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internet_Explorer "Internet Explorer") with Windows.[[10]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-Allan_2001-13): 323–324

[![Image 18](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/04/Microsoft_IntelliMouse_2001.jpg/250px-Microsoft_IntelliMouse_2001.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Microsoft_IntelliMouse_2001.jpg)

While primarily focused on software, Microsoft also produced a number of successful PC accessories, such as the [IntelliMouse](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IntelliMouse "IntelliMouse") computer mice shown here

[![Image 19](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/Xbox-console.jpg/250px-Xbox-console.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Xbox-console.jpg)

Microsoft released the first installment in the [Xbox](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xbox "Xbox") series of consoles in 2001. The [Xbox](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xbox_(console) "Xbox (console)"), graphically powerful compared to its rivals, featured a standard PC's 733 MHz Intel Pentium III processor.

On January 13, 2000, Bill Gates handed over the CEO position to [Steve Ballmer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Steve_Ballmer "Steve Ballmer"), an old college friend of Gates and employee of the company since 1980, while creating a new position for himself as Chief [Software Architect](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Software_architect "Software architect").[[10]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-Allan_2001-13): 111, 228 [[14]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-BBCTL-17) Various companies including Microsoft formed the [Trusted Computing Platform Alliance](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trusted_Computing_Group "Trusted Computing Group") in October 1999 to (among other things) increase security and protect [intellectual property](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intellectual_property "Intellectual property") through identifying changes in hardware and software. Critics decried the alliance as a way to enforce indiscriminate restrictions over how consumers use software, and over how computers behave, and as a form of [digital rights management](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Digital_rights_management "Digital rights management"): for example, the scenario where a computer is not only secured for its owner but also secured against its owner as well.[[44]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-47)[[45]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-48) On April 3, 2000, a judgment was handed down in the case of _[United States v. Microsoft Corp.](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United\_States\_v.\_Microsoft\_Corp. "United States v. Microsoft Corp.")_,[[46]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-49) calling the company an "abusive monopoly."[[47]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-50) Microsoft later settled with the U.S. Department of Justice in 2004.[[26]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-CBSCHRON-29)

On October 25, 2001, Microsoft released [Windows XP](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Windows_XP "Windows XP"), unifying the mainstream and NT lines of OS under the NT codebase.[[48]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-51) The company released the [Xbox](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xbox_(console) "Xbox (console)") later that year, entering the [video game console](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Video_game_console "Video game console") market dominated by [Sony](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sony "Sony") and [Nintendo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nintendo "Nintendo").[[49]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-52) In March 2004 the [European Union](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/European_Union "European Union") brought [antitrust legal action against the company](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft_Corp._v._Commission "Microsoft Corp. v. Commission"), citing it abused its dominance with the Windows OS, resulting in a judgment of €497 million ($613 million) and requiring Microsoft to produce new versions of Windows XP without [Windows Media Player](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Windows_Media_Player "Windows Media Player"): Windows XP Home Edition N and Windows XP Professional N.[[50]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-53)[[51]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-54) In November 2005, the company's second video game console, the [Xbox 360](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xbox_360 "Xbox 360"), was released. There were two versions, a basic version for $299.99 and a deluxe version for $399.99.[[52]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-55)

Increasingly present in the hardware business following Xbox, Microsoft 2006 released the [Zune](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zune "Zune") series of digital media players, a successor of its previous software platform [Portable Media Center](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Portable_Media_Center "Portable Media Center"). These expanded on previous hardware commitments from Microsoft following its original [Microsoft Mouse](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft_Mouse "Microsoft Mouse") in 1983; as of 2007 the company sold the best-selling wired keyboard ([Natural Ergonomic Keyboard 4000](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft_ergonomic_keyboards "Microsoft ergonomic keyboards")), mouse ([IntelliMouse](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IntelliMouse "IntelliMouse")), and desktop webcam ([LifeCam](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LifeCam "LifeCam")) in the United States. That year the company also launched the Surface "digital table", later renamed [PixelSense](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft_PixelSense "Microsoft PixelSense").[[53]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-56)

### 2007–2011: Microsoft Azure, Windows Vista, Windows 7, and Microsoft Stores

[![Image 20](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/10/Steve_Ballmer_-_MIX_2008.jpg/250px-Steve_Ballmer_-_MIX_2008.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Steve_Ballmer_-_MIX_2008.jpg)

CEO [Steve Ballmer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Steve_Ballmer "Steve Ballmer") at the [MIX](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MIX_(Microsoft) "MIX (Microsoft)") event in 2008. In an interview about his management style in 2005, he mentioned that his first priority was to get the people he delegates to in order. Ballmer also emphasized the need to continue pursuing new technologies even if initial attempts fail, citing the original attempts with Windows as an example.[[54]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-57)

[![Image 21](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d2/Belgique_-_Bruxelles_-_Schuman_-_Berlaymont_-_01.jpg/250px-Belgique_-_Bruxelles_-_Schuman_-_Berlaymont_-_01.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Belgique_-_Bruxelles_-_Schuman_-_Berlaymont_-_01.jpg)

Headquarters of the [European Commission](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/European_Commission "European Commission"), which has imposed several fines on Microsoft

Released in January 2007, the next version of Windows, [Vista](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Windows_Vista "Windows Vista"), focused on features, security and a redesigned user interface dubbed [Aero](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Windows_Aero "Windows Aero").[[55]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-58)[[56]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-59)[Microsoft Office 2007](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft_Office_2007 "Microsoft Office 2007"), released at the same time, featured a "[Ribbon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ribbon_(computing) "Ribbon (computing)")" user interface which was a significant departure from its predecessors. Relatively strong sales of both products helped to produce a record profit in 2007.[[57]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-60) The European Union imposed another fine of €899 million ($1.4 billion) for Microsoft's lack of compliance with the March 2004 judgment on February 27, 2008, saying that the company charged rivals unreasonable prices for key information about its [workgroup](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft_SQL_Server "Microsoft SQL Server") and [backoffice](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft_BackOffice_Server "Microsoft BackOffice Server") servers.[[58]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-61) Microsoft stated that it was in compliance and that "these fines are about the past issues that have been resolved".[[59]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-62) 2007 also saw the creation of a multi-core unit at Microsoft, following the steps of server companies such as Sun and IBM.[[60]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-63)

Gates retired from his role as Chief Software Architect on June 27, 2008, a decision announced in June 2006, while retaining other positions related to the company in addition to being an advisor for the company on key projects.[[61]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-64)[[62]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-65)[Azure Services Platform](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft_Azure "Microsoft Azure"), the company's entry into the [cloud computing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cloud_computing "Cloud computing") market for Windows, launched on October 27, 2008.[[63]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-66) On February 12, 2009, Microsoft announced its intent to open a chain of Microsoft-branded retail stores, and on October 22, 2009, the first retail [Microsoft Store](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft_Store_(retail) "Microsoft Store (retail)") opened in [Scottsdale, Arizona](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scottsdale,_Arizona "Scottsdale, Arizona"); the same day [Windows 7](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Windows_7 "Windows 7") was officially released to the public. Windows 7's focus was on refining Vista with ease-of-use features and performance enhancements, rather than an extensive reworking of Windows.[[64]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-67)[[65]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-68)[[66]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-69)

As the smartphone industry boomed in the late 2000s, Microsoft had struggled to keep up with its rivals in providing a modern smartphone operating system, falling behind [Apple](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Apple_Inc. "Apple Inc.") and [Google](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Google "Google")-sponsored [Android](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Android_(operating_system) "Android (operating system)") in the United States.[[67]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-70) As a result, in 2010 Microsoft revamped their aging flagship mobile operating system, [Windows Mobile](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Windows_Mobile "Windows Mobile"), replacing it with the new [Windows Phone](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Windows_Phone "Windows Phone") OS that was released in October that year.[[68]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-71)[[69]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-72) It used a new user interface design language, codenamed "Metro", which prominently used simple shapes, typography, and iconography, utilizing the concept of minimalism. Microsoft implemented a new strategy for the software industry, providing a consistent user experience across all smartphones using the Windows Phone OS. It launched an alliance with [Nokia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nokia "Nokia") in 2011 and Microsoft worked closely with the company to co-develop Windows Phone,[[70]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-73) but remained partners with long-time Windows Mobile [OEM](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Original_equipment_manufacturer "Original equipment manufacturer")[HTC](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HTC "HTC").[[71]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-74) Microsoft is a founding member of the [Open Networking Foundation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Open_Networking_Foundation "Open Networking Foundation") started on March 23, 2011. Fellow founders were [Google](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Google "Google"), [HPE Networking](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HPE_Networking "HPE Networking"), [Yahoo!](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yahoo! "Yahoo!"), [Verizon Communications](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Verizon#History "Verizon"), [Deutsche Telekom](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deutsche_Telekom "Deutsche Telekom") and 17 other companies. This nonprofit organization is focused on providing support for a [cloud computing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cloud_computing "Cloud computing") initiative called Software-Defined Networking.[[72]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-75) The initiative is meant to speed innovation through simple software changes in telecommunications networks, wireless networks, data centers, and other networking areas.[[73]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-76)

### 2011–2014: Windows 8/8.1, Xbox One, Outlook.com, and Surface devices

Following the release of [Windows Phone](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Windows_Phone "Windows Phone"), Microsoft undertook a gradual [rebranding](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rebranding "Rebranding") of its product range throughout 2011 and 2012, with the corporation's logos, products, services, and websites adopting the principles and concepts of the [Metro design language](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metro_(design_language) "Metro (design language)").[[74]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-77) Microsoft unveiled [Windows computer"), in Taipei in June 2011.[[75]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-78) A developer preview was released on September 13, which was subsequently replaced by a consumer preview 2012").[[81]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-84)

In July 2012, Microsoft sold its 50% stake in MSNBC, which it had run as a joint venture with NBC since 1996.[[82]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-85) On October 1, 2012, Microsoft announced its intention to launch a news operation, part of a new-look [MSN](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MSN "MSN"), with Windows 8 later in the month.[[83]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-86) On October 26, 2012, Microsoft launched Windows 8 and the [Microsoft Surface](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft_Surface "Microsoft Surface").[[78]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-VF2012-81)[[84]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-87) Three days later, [Windows Phone 8](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Windows_Phone_8 "Windows Phone 8") was launched.[[85]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-88) To cope with the potential for an increase in demand for products and services, Microsoft opened a number of "holiday stores" across the U.S. to complement the increasing number of "bricks-and-mortar" Microsoft Stores that opened in 2012.[[86]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-89) On March 29, 2013, Microsoft launched a Patent Tracker.[[87]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-90)

The [Xbox One](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xbox_One "Xbox One") console, released in 2013

The [Kinect](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kinect "Kinect"), a motion-sensing input device made by Microsoft and designed as a [video game controller](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Game_controller "Game controller"), first introduced in November 2010, was upgraded for the 2013 release of the [Xbox One](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xbox_One "Xbox One") video game console. Kinect's capabilities were revealed in May 2013: an ultra-wide 1080p camera, function in the dark due to an infrared sensor, higher-end processing power and new software, the ability to distinguish between fine movements (such as a thumb movement), and determining a user's heart rate by looking at their face.[[89]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-92) Microsoft filed a patent application in 2011 that suggests that the corporation may use the Kinect camera system to monitor the behavior of television viewers as part of a plan to make the viewing experience more interactive.[[90]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-93) On July 19, 2013, Microsoft stocks suffered their biggest one-day percentage sell-off since the year 2000, after its fourth-quarter report raised concerns among investors on the poor showings of both Windows 8 and the Surface tablet. Microsoft suffered a loss of more than US$32 billion.[[91]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-94)

In line with the maturing PC business, in July 2013, Microsoft announced that it would reorganize the business into four new business divisions, namely Operating systems, Apps, Cloud, and Devices. All previous divisions will be dissolved into new divisions without any workforce cuts.[[92]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-95) On September 3, 2013, Microsoft agreed to buy [Nokia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nokia "Nokia")'s mobile unit for $7 billion,[[93]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-96) following [Amy Hood](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amy_Hood "Amy Hood") taking the role of CFO.[[94]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-97)

### 2014–2020: Windows 10, Microsoft Edge, and HoloLens

[![Image 24](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/19/Satya_smiling-print.jpg/250px-Satya_smiling-print.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Satya_smiling-print.jpg)

[Satya Nadella](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Satya_Nadella "Satya Nadella") succeeded [Steve Ballmer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Steve_Ballmer "Steve Ballmer") as the [CEO](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chief_executive_officer "Chief executive officer") of Microsoft in February 2014.

On February 4, 2014, [Steve Ballmer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Steve_Ballmer "Steve Ballmer") stepped down as [CEO](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chief_executive_officer "Chief executive officer") of Microsoft and was succeeded by [Satya Nadella](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Satya_Nadella "Satya Nadella"), who previously led Microsoft's Cloud and Enterprise division.[[95]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-98) On the same day, [John W. Thompson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_W._Thompson "John W. Thompson") took on the role of chairman, in place of Bill Gates, who continued to participate as a technology advisor.[[96]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-chairex-99) Thompson became the second chairman in Microsoft's history.[[97]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-100) On April 25, 2014, Microsoft acquired Nokia Devices and Services for $7.2 billion.[[98]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-101) This new subsidiary was renamed Microsoft Mobile Oy.[[99]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-102) On September 15, 2014, Microsoft acquired the video game development company [Mojang](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mojang "Mojang"), best known for _[Minecraft](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Minecraft "Minecraft")_, for $2.5 billion.[[100]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-103) On June 8, 2017, Microsoft acquired [Hexadite](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hexadite "Hexadite"), an Israeli security firm, for $100 million.[[101]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-104)[[102]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-105)

On January 21, 2015, Microsoft announced the release of their first [interactive whiteboard](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interactive_whiteboard "Interactive whiteboard"), named [Surface Hub](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Surface_Hub "Surface Hub").[[103]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-106) On July 29, 2015, [Windows 10](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Windows_10 "Windows 10") was released,[[104]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-107) with its server sibling, [Windows Server 2016](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Windows_Server_2016 "Windows Server 2016"), released in September 2016. In Q1 2015, Microsoft was the [third-largest maker of mobile phones](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_best-selling_mobile_phones#Annual_sales_by_manufacturer "List of best-selling mobile phones"), selling 33 million units (7.2% of all). While a large majority (at least 75%) of them do not run any version of [Windows Phone](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Windows_Phone "Windows Phone") — those other phones are not categorized as [smartphones](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Smartphone "Smartphone") by Gartner– in the same timeframe 8 million Windows smartphones (2.5% of all smartphones) were made by all manufacturers (mostly Microsoft).[[105]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-108) Microsoft's share of the U.S. smartphone market in January 2016 was 2.7%.[[106]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-109) During the summer of 2015 the company lost $7.6 billion related to its mobile-phone business, firing 7,800 employees.[[107]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-WSJ:_Microsoft_to_Streamline_Smartphone_Hardware_Business-110)

In 2015, the construction of a data center in [Mecklenburg County](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mecklenburg_County,_Virginia "Mecklenburg County, Virginia"), [Virginia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Virginia "Virginia"), led to the destruction of a historic [African American](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/African_Americans "African Americans") cemetery despite archeological recommendations for preservation.[[108]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-111)

On March 1, 2016, Microsoft announced the merger of its PC and Xbox divisions, with [Phil Spencer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phil_Spencer_(business_executive) "Phil Spencer (business executive)") announcing that Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps would be the focus for Microsoft's gaming in the future.[[109]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-112) On January 24, 2017, Microsoft showcased Intune for Education at the [BETT](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BETT "BETT") 2017 education technology conference in [London](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/London "London").[[110]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-113) Intune for Education is a new cloud-based application and device management service for the education sector.[[111]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-114) In May 2016, the company announced it was laying off 1,850 workers, and taking an impairment and restructuring charge of $950 million.[[107]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-WSJ:_Microsoft_to_Streamline_Smartphone_Hardware_Business-110)

In June 2016, Microsoft announced a project named Microsoft Azure Information Protection. It aims to help enterprises protect their data as it moves between servers and devices.[[112]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-115) In November 2016, Microsoft joined the [Linux Foundation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linux_Foundation "Linux Foundation") as a Platinum member during Microsoft's Connect(); developer event in New York.[[113]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-116) The cost of each Platinum membership is US$500,000 per year.[[114]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-117) Some analysts deemed this unthinkable ten years prior, however, as in 2001 then-CEO Steve Ballmer called Linux "cancer".[[115]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-118) Microsoft planned to launch a preview of Intune for Education "in the coming weeks", with general availability scheduled for spring 2017, priced at $30 per device, or through volume licensing agreements.[[116]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-119)

The [Nokia Lumia 1320](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nokia_Lumia_1320 "Nokia Lumia 1320"), the [Microsoft Lumia 535](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft_Lumia_535 "Microsoft Lumia 535") and the [Nokia Lumia 530](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nokia_Lumia_530 "Nokia Lumia 530"), which all run on one of the now-discontinued [Windows Phone](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Windows_Phone "Windows Phone") operating systems

In April the company further expressed willingness to embrace open source initiatives by announcing [Azure Sphere](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Azure_Sphere "Azure Sphere") as its own derivative of the [Linux](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linux "Linux") operating system.[[117]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-TheRegister2018-120) In May 2018, Microsoft partnered with 17 American intelligence agencies to develop [cloud computing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cloud_computing "Cloud computing") products. The project is dubbed "Azure Government" and has ties to the [Joint Enterprise Defense Infrastructure](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joint_Enterprise_Defense_Infrastructure "Joint Enterprise Defense Infrastructure") (JEDI) surveillance program.[[117]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-TheRegister2018-120) On June 4, 2018, Microsoft officially announced the acquisition of [GitHub](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/GitHub "GitHub") for $7.5 billion, a deal that closed on October 26, 2018.[[118]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-121)[[119]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-122) On July 10, 2018, Microsoft revealed the [Surface Go](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft_Surface_Go "Microsoft Surface Go") platform to the public. Later in the month, it converted [Microsoft Teams](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft_Teams "Microsoft Teams") to [gratis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gratis_versus_libre "Gratis versus libre").[[117]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-TheRegister2018-120) In August 2018, Microsoft released two projects called Microsoft AccountGuard and Defending Democracy. It also unveiled [Snapdragon 850](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Qualcomm_Snapdragon "Qualcomm Snapdragon") compatibility for [Windows 10](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Windows_10 "Windows 10") on the [ARM architecture](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ARM_architecture "ARM architecture").[[120]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-123)[[121]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-124)[[117]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-TheRegister2018-120)

[![Image 26](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c5/Apollo_11_astronaut_Buzz_Aldrin_tries_out_Microsoft_HoloLens_%2829794543715%29.jpg/250px-Apollo_11_astronaut_Buzz_Aldrin_tries_out_Microsoft_HoloLens_%2829794543715%29.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Apollo_11_astronaut_Buzz_Aldrin_tries_out_Microsoft_HoloLens_(29794543715).jpg)

[Apollo 11](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Apollo_11 "Apollo 11") astronaut [Buzz Aldrin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Buzz_Aldrin "Buzz Aldrin") using a [Microsoft HoloLens](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft_HoloLens "Microsoft HoloLens") mixed reality headset in September 2016

In August 2018, [Toyota Tsusho](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Toyota_Tsusho "Toyota Tsusho") began a partnership with Microsoft to create [fish farming](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fish_farming "Fish farming") tools using the Microsoft Azure application suite for [Internet of things](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internet_of_things "Internet of things") (IoT) technologies related to water management. Developed in part by researchers from [Kindai University](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kindai_University "Kindai University"), the water pump mechanisms use [artificial intelligence](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence "Artificial intelligence") to count the number of fish on a [conveyor belt](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conveyor_belt "Conveyor belt"), analyze the number of fish, and deduce the effectiveness of water flow from the data the fish provide. The specific [computer programs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computer_program "Computer program") used in the process fall under the Azure Machine Learning and the Azure IoT Hub platforms.[[122]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-125)

In September 2018, Microsoft discontinued [Skype Classic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Skype "Skype").[[117]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-TheRegister2018-120) On October 10, 2018, Microsoft joined the [Open Invention Network](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Open_Invention_Network "Open Invention Network") community despite holding more than 60,000 patents.[[123]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-126) In November 2018, Microsoft agreed to supply 100,000 [Microsoft HoloLens](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft_HoloLens "Microsoft HoloLens") headsets to the [United States military](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Armed_Forces "United States Armed Forces") in order to "increase lethality by enhancing the ability to detect, decide and engage before the enemy."[[124]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-127) In November 2018, Microsoft introduced Azure Multi-Factor Authentication for Microsoft Azure.[[125]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-R1BDM-128) In December 2018, Microsoft announced [Project Mu](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/TianoCore_EDK_II#Project_Mu "TianoCore EDK II"), an [open source](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Open_source "Open source") release of the [Unified Extensible Firmware Interface](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UEFI "UEFI") (UEFI) core used in [Microsoft Surface](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft_Surface "Microsoft Surface") and [Hyper-V](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hyper-V "Hyper-V") products. The project promotes the idea of [Firmware as a Service](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/TianoCore_EDK_II#Project_Mu "TianoCore EDK II").[[126]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-129) In the same month, Microsoft announced the [open source](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Open_source "Open source") implementation of [Windows Forms](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Windows_Forms "Windows Forms") and the [Windows Presentation Foundation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Windows_Presentation_Foundation "Windows Presentation Foundation") (WPF) which will allow for further movement of the company toward the transparent release of key frameworks used in developing Windows desktop applications and software. December also saw the company discontinue the [Microsoft Edge [Legacy]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft_Edge_Legacy "Microsoft Edge Legacy") browser project in favor of the ["New Edge"](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft_Edge "Microsoft Edge") browser project, featuring a [Chromium](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chromium_(web_browser) "Chromium (web browser)") based backend.[[125]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-R1BDM-128)

On February 20, 2019, Microsoft Corp said it will offer its cyber security service AccountGuard to 12 new markets in Europe including Germany, France and Spain, to close security gaps and protect customers in political space from hacking.[[127]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-130) In February 2019, hundreds of Microsoft employees protested the company's [war profiteering](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/War_profiteering "War profiteering") from a $480 million contract to develop [virtual reality headsets](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Virtual_reality_headset "Virtual reality headset") for the [United States Army](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Army "United States Army").[[128]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-131)

### 2020–present: Acquisitions, Xbox Series X/S, and Windows 11

See also: [Acquisition of Activision Blizzard by Microsoft](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Acquisition_of_Activision_Blizzard_by_Microsoft "Acquisition of Activision Blizzard by Microsoft")

On March 26, 2020, Microsoft announced it was acquiring Affirmed Networks for about $1.35 billion.[[129]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-132)[[130]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-133) Due to the [COVID-19 pandemic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic "COVID-19 pandemic"), Microsoft closed all of its retail stores indefinitely due to health concerns.[[131]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-134) On July 22, 2020, Microsoft announced plans to close its [Mixer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mixer_(service) "Mixer (service)") service, planning to move existing partners to [Facebook Gaming](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Facebook_features#Facebook_Gaming "List of Facebook features").[[132]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-135)

On July 31, 2020, it was reported that Microsoft was in talks to acquire [TikTok](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/TikTok "TikTok") after the [Trump administration](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/First_presidency_of_Donald_Trump "First presidency of Donald Trump") ordered [ByteDance](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ByteDance "ByteDance") to [divest](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Divestment "Divestment") ownership of the application to the U.S.[[133]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-136) On August 3, 2020, after speculation on the deal, [Donald Trump](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump "Donald Trump") stated that Microsoft could buy the application, however, it should be completed by September 15, 2020, and that the [United States Department of the Treasury](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Department_of_the_Treasury "United States Department of the Treasury") should receive a portion if it were to go through.[[134]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-137)

On August 5, 2020, Microsoft stopped its [xCloud](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xbox_Cloud_Gaming#iOS "Xbox Cloud Gaming") game streaming test for [iOS](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IOS "IOS") devices. According to Microsoft, the future of xCloud on iOS remains unclear and potentially out of Microsoft's hands. [Apple](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Apple_Inc. "Apple Inc.") has imposed a strict limit on "[remote desktop clients](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Remote_Desktop_Services "Remote Desktop Services")" which means applications are only allowed to connect to a user-owned host device or gaming console owned by the user.[[135]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-138) On September 21, 2020, Microsoft announced its intent to acquire video game company [ZeniMax Media](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ZeniMax_Media "ZeniMax Media"), the parent company of [Bethesda Softworks](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bethesda_Softworks "Bethesda Softworks"), for about $7.5 billion, with the deal expected to occur in the second half of 2021 fiscal year.[[136]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-139) On March 9, 2021, the acquisition was finalized and ZeniMax Media became part of Microsoft's Xbox Game Studios division.[[137]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-140) The total price of the deal was $8.1 billion.[[138]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-141)

On September 22, 2020, Microsoft announced that it had an exclusive license to use [OpenAI](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/OpenAI "OpenAI")'s GPT-3 artificial intelligence language generator.[[139]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-142) The previous version of [GPT-3](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/GPT-3 "GPT-3"), called [GPT-2](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/GPT-2 "GPT-2"), made headlines for being "too dangerous to release" and had numerous capabilities, including designing websites, prescribing medication, answering questions, and penning articles.[[140]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-143)

On November 10, 2020, Microsoft released the [Xbox Series X and Xbox Series S](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xbox_Series_X_and_Series_S "Xbox Series X and Series S") video game consoles.[[141]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-144)

In February 2021, Microsoft released [Azure Quantum](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Azure_Quantum "Azure Quantum") for public preview.[[142]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-145) The public cloud computing platform provides access to quantum software and quantum hardware including [trapped ion](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trapped_ion_quantum_computer "Trapped ion quantum computer"), [neutral atom](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neutral_atom_quantum_computer "Neutral atom quantum computer"), and [superconducting](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Superconducting_quantum_computing "Superconducting quantum computing") systems.[[143]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-146)[[144]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-147)[[145]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-148)[[146]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-149)

In April 2021, Microsoft announced it would buy [Nuance Communications](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nuance_Communications "Nuance Communications") for approximately $16 billion.[[147]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-150) The acquisition of Nuance was completed in March 2022.[[148]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-151) In 2021, in part due to the strong quarterly earnings spurred by the [COVID-19 pandemic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic "COVID-19 pandemic"), Microsoft's valuation came to nearly $2 trillion. The increased necessity for [remote work](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Remote_work "Remote work") and [distance education](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distance_education "Distance education") drove demand for [cloud computing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cloud_computing "Cloud computing") and grew the company's gaming sales.[[149]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-152)[[150]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-153)[[151]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-154)

On June 24, 2021, Microsoft announced [Windows 11](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Windows_11 "Windows 11") during a Livestream. The announcement came with confusion after Microsoft announced Windows 10 would be the last version of the operating system.[[152]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-155) It was released to the general public on October 5, 2021.[[153]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-156)

In September 2021, it was announced that the company had acquired Takelessons, an online platform that connects students and tutors in numerous subjects. The acquisition positioned Microsoft to grow its presence in the market of providing online education to large numbers of people.[[154]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-157) In the same month, Microsoft acquired Australia-based video editing software company [Clipchamp](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clipchamp "Clipchamp").[[155]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-158)

In October 2021, Microsoft announced that it began rolling out end-to-end encryption (E2EE) support for Microsoft Teams calls in order to secure business communication while using video conferencing software. Users can ensure that their calls are encrypted and can utilize a security code that both parties on a call must verify on their respective ends.[[156]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-159) On October 7, Microsoft acquired Ally.io, a software service that measures companies' progress against [OKRs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/OKR "OKR"). Microsoft plans to incorporate Ally.io into its Viva family of employee experience products.[[157]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-160)

On January 18, 2022, Microsoft announced the acquisition of American video game developer and [holding company](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Holding_company "Holding company")[Activision Blizzard](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Activision_Blizzard "Activision Blizzard") in an all-cash deal worth $68.7 billion.[[158]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-Warren2022-161) Activision Blizzard is best known for producing franchises, including but not limited to _[Warcraft](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Warcraft "Warcraft")_, _[Diablo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diablo\_(series) "Diablo (series)")_, _[Call of Duty](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Call\_of\_Duty "Call of Duty")_, _[StarCraft](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/StarCraft "StarCraft")_, _[Candy Crush Saga](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Candy\_Crush\_Saga "Candy Crush Saga")_, _[Crash Bandicoot](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crash\_Bandicoot "Crash Bandicoot")_, _[Spyro](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spyro "Spyro")_, _[Tony Hawk's](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tony\_Hawk%27s "Tony Hawk's")_, _[Guitar Hero](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guitar\_Hero "Guitar Hero")_, and _[Overwatch](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Overwatch "Overwatch")_.[[159]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-162) Activision and Microsoft each released statements saying the acquisition was to benefit their businesses in the [metaverse](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metaverse "Metaverse"), many saw Microsoft's acquisition of video game studios as an attempt to compete against [Meta Platforms](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Meta_Platforms "Meta Platforms"), with _[TheStreet](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/TheStreet "TheStreet")_ referring to Microsoft wanting to become "the [Disney](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Walt_Disney_Company "The Walt Disney Company") of the metaverse".[[160]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-163)[[161]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-164) Microsoft also named [Phil Spencer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phil_Spencer_(business_executive) "Phil Spencer (business executive)"), head of the Xbox brand since 2014, the inaugural CEO of the newly established [Microsoft Gaming](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft_Gaming "Microsoft Gaming") division, which now houses the Xbox operations team and the three publishers in the company's portfolio (Xbox Game Studios, ZeniMax Media, Activision Blizzard). Microsoft has not released statements regarding Activision's recent legal controversies regarding employee abuse, but reports have alleged that Activision CEO [Bobby Kotick](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bobby_Kotick "Bobby Kotick"), a major target of the controversy, will leave the company after the acquisition is finalized.[[162]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-165) The deal was closed on October 13, 2023.[[163]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-166)

In December 2022, Microsoft announced a new 10-year deal with the [London Stock Exchange Group](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/London_Stock_Exchange_Group "London Stock Exchange Group") for products including Microsoft Azure; Microsoft acquired around 4% of LSEG as part of the deal.[[164]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-167)

In January 2023, CEO Satya Nadella announced Microsoft would lay off some 10,000 employees.[[165]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-168) The announcement came a day after hosting a [Sting](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sting_(musician) "Sting (musician)") concert for 50 people, including Microsoft executives, in [Davos](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Davos "Davos"), Switzerland.[[166]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-169)

On January 23, 2023, Microsoft announced a new multi-year, multi-billion dollar investment deal with [ChatGPT](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ChatGPT "ChatGPT") developer [OpenAI](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/OpenAI "OpenAI").[[167]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-170)

In June 2023, Microsoft released Azure Quantum Elements to run molecular simulations and calculations in [computational chemistry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computational_chemistry "Computational chemistry") and materials science using a combination of AI, high-performance computing and [quantum computing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_computing "Quantum computing").[[168]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-AQE-171) The service includes Copilot, a GPT-4 based large language model tool to query and visualize data, write code, initiate simulations, and educate researchers.[[168]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-AQE-171)

At a November 2023 developer conference, Microsoft announced two new custom-designed computing chips: The Maia chip, designed to run large language models, and Cobalt CPU, designed to power general cloud services on Azure.[[169]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-172)[[170]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-173)

On November 20, 2023, Satya Nadella announced that [Sam Altman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sam_Altman "Sam Altman"), who had been [ousted as CEO of OpenAI](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Removal_of_Sam_Altman_from_OpenAI "Removal of Sam Altman from OpenAI") just days earlier, and [Greg Brockman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Greg_Brockman "Greg Brockman"), who had resigned as president, would join Microsoft to lead a new advanced AI research team.[[171]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-174)[[172]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-175) However, the plan was short-lived, as Altman was subsequently reinstated as OpenAI's CEO and Brockman rejoined the company amid pressure from OpenAI's employees and investors on its board.[[173]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-176) In March 2024, [Inflection AI](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inflection_AI "Inflection AI")'s cofounders [Mustafa Suleyman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mustafa_Suleyman "Mustafa Suleyman") and Karen Simonyan announced their departure from the company in order to start Microsoft AI, with Microsoft [acqui-hiring](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Acqui-hiring "Acqui-hiring") nearly the entirety of its 70-person workforce. As part of the deal, Microsoft paid Inflection $650 million to license its technology.[[174]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-177)[[175]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-178)

In January 2024, Microsoft became the most valued publicly traded company. Meanwhile, that month, the company announced a subscription offering of artificial intelligence for small businesses via Copilot Pro.[[176]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-179)[[177]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-180)

In April 2024, Microsoft made a $1.5 billion investment in the Emirati AI firm [G42](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/G42_(company) "G42 (company)"). As part of the deal, G42 said it would use the Microsoft Azure platform for its AI development and deployment.[[178]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-181)[[179]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-182) Later that month, Microsoft unveiled plans to invest $1.7 billion in developing AI and cloud infrastructure in Indonesia. The plan includes establishment of data centers and partnerships to support digital transformation efforts.[[180]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-183)

In May 2024, Microsoft announced a $3.3 billion investment to build an artificial intelligence hub in southeast [Wisconsin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wisconsin "Wisconsin"), tripling its initial proposal. This initiative, unveiled by President [Joe Biden](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joe_Biden "Joe Biden") in [Racine County](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Racine_County,_Wisconsin "Racine County, Wisconsin"), includes constructing a data center, creating 2,300 construction jobs by 2025, and 2,000 permanent jobs over time, alongside establishing an AI co-innovation lab at [UW-Milwaukee](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Wisconsin%E2%80%93Milwaukee "University of Wisconsin–Milwaukee") to train up to 1,000 individuals by 2030.[[181]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-184)

In June 2024, Microsoft announced it would be laying off 1,000 employees from the company's mixed reality and Azure cloud computing divisions.[[182]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-185)[[183]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-186)

In June 2024, Microsoft announced that they were building a "hyperscale data centre" in South East Leeds.[[184]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-187) In July 2024, it was reported that the company was laying off its [diversity, equity, and inclusion](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diversity,_equity,_and_inclusion "Diversity, equity, and inclusion") (DEI) team.[[185]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-188)[[186]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-189)

On July 19, 2024, a [global IT outage](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2024_CrowdStrike-related_IT_outages "2024 CrowdStrike-related IT outages") impacted Microsoft services, affecting businesses, airlines, and financial institutions worldwide. The outage was traced back to a flawed update of [CrowdStrike](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CrowdStrike "CrowdStrike")'s cybersecurity software, which resulted in Microsoft systems crashing and causing disruptions across various sectors. Despite CrowdStrike's CEO [George Kurtz](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/George_Kurtz "George Kurtz") clarifying that the issue was not a cyberattack, the incident had widespread consequences, leading to delays in air travel, financial transactions, and medical services globally. Microsoft stated that the underlying cause had been fixed but acknowledged ongoing residual impacts on some [Microsoft 365](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft_365 "Microsoft 365") apps and services.[[187]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-190)[[188]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-191)

In September 2024, [BlackRock](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BlackRock "BlackRock") and Microsoft announced a $30 billion fund, the Global AI Infrastructure Investment Partnership, to invest in AI infrastructure such as data centers and energy projects. The fund has the potential to reach $100 billion with debt financing, and partners include [Abu Dhabi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Abu_Dhabi "Abu Dhabi")-backed MGX and [Nvidia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nvidia "Nvidia"), which will provide AI expertise. Investments will primarily focus on the U.S., with some in partner countries.[[189]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-192) Microsoft also announced relaunch of its controversial tool, Recall, in November 2024 after addressing privacy concerns. Initially criticized for taking regular screenshots without user consent, Recall was changed to an opt-in feature instead of being default on. The UK's Information Commissioner's Office monitored the situation and noted the adjustments, which included enhanced security measures like encryption and biometric access. While experts regarded these changes as improvements, they advised caution, with some recommending further testing before users opted in.[[190]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-193)

On February 28, 2025, Microsoft announced that Skype would be shutting down on May 5, 2025, to streamline its focus on Microsoft Teams. The company stated there would be no job cuts due to the shutdown.[[191]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-194)

On April 4, 2025, it celebrated its [50th anniversary](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/50th_anniversary "50th anniversary").[[192]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-ms_50th-195)

On May 30, 2025, it was reported that Microsoft's Russian division would be preparing to file for bankruptcy, days after President [Vladimir Putin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vladimir_Putin "Vladimir Putin") stated that foreign services providers should be throttled in Russia to make way for domestic software, which included Microsoft. The company previously restructured operations in Russia back in June 2022 after being significantly impacted from the Ukraine war, but they stated those restructuring efforts have failed.[[193]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-196)

Corporate affairs
-----------------

Microsoft is ranked No. 14 in the 2022 [_Fortune_ 500](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fortune_500 "Fortune 500") rankings of the [largest United States corporations by total revenue](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_largest_companies_in_the_United_States_by_revenue "List of largest companies in the United States by revenue");[[194]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-197) and it was the world's [largest software maker](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_the_largest_software_companies "List of the largest software companies") by revenue in 2022 according to [_Forbes_ Global 2000](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Forbes_Global_2000 "Forbes Global 2000").
