### Board of directors

The company is run by a [board of directors](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Board_of_directors "Board of directors") made up of mostly company outsiders, as is customary for publicly traded companies. Members of the board of directors as of December 2023 are [Satya Nadella](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Satya_Nadella "Satya Nadella"), [Reid Hoffman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reid_Hoffman "Reid Hoffman"), Hugh Johnston, Teri List, [Sandi Peterson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sandi_Peterson "Sandi Peterson"), [Penny Pritzker](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Penny_Pritzker "Penny Pritzker"), Carlos Rodriguez, [Charles Scharf](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charles_Scharf "Charles Scharf"), [John W. Stanton](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_W._Stanton "John W. Stanton"), [John W. Thompson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_W._Thompson "John W. Thompson"), [Emma Walmsley](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emma_Walmsley "Emma Walmsley") and [Padmasree Warrior](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Padmasree_Warrior "Padmasree Warrior").[[198]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-202)

Board members are elected every year at the annual shareholders' meeting using a majority vote system. There are four committees within the board that oversee more specific matters. These committees include the Audit Committee, which handles accounting issues with the company including auditing and reporting; the Compensation Committee, which approves compensation for the CEO and other employees of the company; the Governance and Nominating Committee, which handles various corporate matters including the nomination of the board; and the Regulatory and Public Policy Committee, which includes legal/antitrust matters, along with privacy, trade, digital safety, artificial intelligence, and environmental sustainability.[[199]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-203)

On March 13, 2020, Gates announced that he is leaving the board of directors of Microsoft and [Berkshire Hathaway](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berkshire_Hathaway "Berkshire Hathaway") to focus more on his philanthropic efforts. According to Aaron Tilley of _[The Wall Street Journal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The\_Wall\_Street\_Journal "The Wall Street Journal")_ this is "marking the biggest boardroom departure in the tech industry since the death of longtime rival and Apple Inc. co-founder [Steve Jobs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Steve_Jobs "Steve Jobs")."[[200]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-204)

On January 13, 2022, _The Wall Street Journal_ reported that Microsoft's board of directors plans to hire an external [law firm](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Law_firm "Law firm") to review its [sexual harassment](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sexual_harassment "Sexual harassment") and [gender discrimination](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gender_discrimination "Gender discrimination") policies, and to release a summary of how the company handled past allegations of misconduct against Bill Gates and other corporate executives.[[201]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-205)

### Marketing

[![Image 28](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/Windows_8_Launch_Event_in_Akihabara%2C_Tokyo.jpg/250px-Windows_8_Launch_Event_in_Akihabara%2C_Tokyo.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Windows_8_Launch_Event_in_Akihabara,_Tokyo.jpg)

[Windows 8](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Windows_8 "Windows 8") Launch Event in [Akihabara](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Akihabara "Akihabara"), [Tokyo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tokyo "Tokyo"), on October 25, 2012

In 2004, Microsoft commissioned research firms to do independent studies comparing the [total cost of ownership](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Total_cost_of_ownership "Total cost of ownership") (TCO) of [Windows Server 2003](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Windows_Server_2003 "Windows Server 2003") to [Linux](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linux "Linux"); the firms concluded that companies found Windows easier to administrate than Linux, thus those using Windows would administrate faster resulting in lower costs for their company (i.e. lower TCO).[[224]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-228) This spurred a wave of related studies; a study by the [Yankee Group](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yankee_Group "Yankee Group") concluded that upgrading from one version of Windows Server to another costs a fraction of the [switching costs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Switching_barriers "Switching barriers") from Windows Server to Linux, although companies surveyed noted the increased security and reliability of Linux servers and concern about being locked into using Microsoft products.[[225]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-229) Another study, released by the [Open Source Development Labs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Open_Source_Development_Labs "Open Source Development Labs"), claimed that the Microsoft studies were "simply outdated and one-sided" and their survey concluded that the TCO of Linux was lower due to Linux administrators managing more servers on average and other reasons.[[226]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-230)

As part of the "Get the Facts" campaign, Microsoft highlighted the [.NET Framework](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/.NET_Framework ".NET Framework") trading platform that it had developed in partnership with [Accenture](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Accenture "Accenture") for the [London Stock Exchange](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/London_Stock_Exchange "London Stock Exchange"), claiming that it provided "[five nines](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/High_availability "High availability")" reliability. After suffering extended downtime and unreliability[[227]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-231)[[228]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-232) the London Stock Exchange announced in 2009 that it was planning to drop its Microsoft solution and switch to a Linux-based one in 2010.[[229]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-233)[[230]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-234)

In 2012, Microsoft hired a political pollster named Mark Penn, whom _The New York Times_ called "famous for bulldozing" his political opponents[[231]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-235) as Executive Vice-president, Advertising and Strategy. Penn created a series of negative advertisements targeting one of Microsoft's chief competitors, [Google](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Google "Google"). The advertisements, called "[Scroogled](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scroogled "Scroogled")", attempted to make the case that Google is "screwing" consumers with search results rigged to favor Google's paid advertisers, that [Gmail](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gmail "Gmail") violates the privacy of its users to place ad results related to the content of their emails and shopping results, which favor Google products. Tech publications like [TechCrunch](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/TechCrunch "TechCrunch") were highly critical of the advertising campaign,[[232]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-236) while Google employees embraced it.[[233]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-237)

### Layoffs

In July 2014, Microsoft announced plans to lay off 18,000 employees. Microsoft employed 127,104 people as of June 5, 2014, making this about a 14 percent reduction of its workforce as the biggest Microsoft layoff ever. This included 12,500 professional and factory personnel. Previously, Microsoft had eliminated 5,800 jobs in 2009 in line with the [Great Recession](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_Recession "Great Recession") of 2008–2017.[[234]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-238)[[235]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-239) In September 2014, Microsoft laid off 2,100 people, including 747 people in the Seattle–Redmond area, where the company is headquartered. The firings came as a second wave of the layoffs that were previously announced. This brought the total number to over 15,000 out of the 18,000 expected cuts.[[236]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-240) In October 2014, Microsoft revealed that it was almost done with eliminating 18,000 employees, which was its largest-ever layoff sweep.[[237]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-241) In July 2015, Microsoft announced another 7,800 job cuts in the next several months.[[238]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-242) In May 2016, Microsoft announced another 1,850 job cuts mostly in its Nokia mobile phone division. As a result, the company will record an impairment and restructuring charge of approximately $950 million, of which approximately $200 million will relate to severance payments.[[239]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-243)

Microsoft laid off 1,900 employees in its gaming division in January 2024. The layoffs primarily affected Activision Blizzard employees, but some Xbox and ZeniMax employees were also affected.[[240]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-244) Blizzard [president](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/President_(corporate_title) "President (corporate title)") Mike Ybarra and [chief design officer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chief_design_officer "Chief design officer")[Allen Adham](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Allen_Adham "Allen Adham") also resigned.[[241]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-245)

In May 2025, Microsoft announced that it is laying off more than 6,000 employees, around three percent of the company’s entire workforce.[[242]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-246)

### United States government

Microsoft provides information about reported bugs in their software to intelligence agencies of the United States government, prior to the public release of the fix. A Microsoft spokesperson has stated that the corporation runs several programs that facilitate the sharing of such information with the U.S. government.[[249]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-254) Following media reports about [PRISM](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PRISM_(surveillance_program) "PRISM (surveillance program)"), NSA's massive electronic [surveillance program](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mass_surveillance "Mass surveillance"), in May 2013, several technology companies were identified as participants, including Microsoft.[[250]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-255) According to leaks of said program, Microsoft joined the PRISM program in 2007.[[251]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-256) However, in June 2013, an official statement from Microsoft flatly denied their participation in the program:

> "We provide customer data only when we receive a legally binding order or subpoena to do so, and never on a voluntary basis. In addition, we only ever comply with orders for requests about specific accounts or identifiers. If the government has a broader voluntary national security program to gather customer data, we don't participate in it."[[252]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-257)

During the first six months of 2013, Microsoft received requests that affected between 15,000 and 15,999 accounts.[[253]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-258) In December 2013, the company made a statement to further emphasize the fact that they take their customers' privacy and [data protection](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Information_privacy "Information privacy") very seriously, even saying that "government snooping potentially now constitutes an '[advanced persistent threat](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Advanced_persistent_threat "Advanced persistent threat"),' alongside sophisticated malware and cyber attacks".[[254]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-259) The statement also marked the beginning of three-part program to enhance Microsoft's encryption and transparency efforts. On July 1, 2014, as part of this program, they opened the first (of many) Microsoft Transparency Center, which provides "participating governments with the ability to review [source code](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Source_code "Source code") for our key products, assure themselves of their software integrity, and confirm there are no "[back doors](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Backdoor_(computing) "Backdoor (computing)")."[[255]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-260) Microsoft has also argued that the [United States Congress](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Congress "United States Congress") should enact strong privacy regulations to protect consumer data.[[256]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-261)

In April 2016, the company [sued the U.S. government](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft_v._United_States_(2016) "Microsoft v. United States (2016)"), argued that secrecy orders were preventing the company from disclosing warrants to customers in violation of the company's and customers' rights. Microsoft argued that it was unconstitutional for the government to indefinitely ban Microsoft from informing its users that the government was requesting their emails and other documents and that the [Fourth Amendment](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fourth_Amendment_to_the_United_States_Constitution "Fourth Amendment to the United States Constitution") made it so people or businesses had the right to know if the government searches or seizes their property. On October 23, 2017, Microsoft said it would drop the lawsuit as a result of a policy change by the [United States Department of Justice](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Department_of_Justice "United States Department of Justice") (DoJ). The DoJ had "changed data request rules on alerting the Internet users about agencies accessing their information."

In 2022 Microsoft shared a $9 billion contract from the [United States Department of Defense](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Department_of_Defense "United States Department of Defense") for cloud computing with Amazon, Google, and Oracle.[[257]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-262)

### Security challenges

On a Friday afternoon in January 2024, Microsoft disclosed that a Russian state-sponsored group hacked into its corporate systems. The group, accessed "a very small percentage" of Microsoft corporate email accounts, which also included members of its senior leadership team and employees in its cybersecurity and legal teams.[[258]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-263) Microsoft noted in a blog post that the attack might have been prevented if the accounts in question had enabled [multi-factor authentication](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-factor_authentication "Multi-factor authentication"), a defensive measure which is widely recommended in the industry, including by Microsoft itself.[[259]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-264)

### Corporate culture

Technical references for developers and articles for various Microsoft magazines such as _[Microsoft Systems Journal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft\_Systems\_Journal "Microsoft Systems Journal")_ (_MSJ_) are available through the [Microsoft Developer Network](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft_Developer_Network "Microsoft Developer Network") (MSDN). MSDN also offers subscriptions for companies and individuals, and the more expensive subscriptions usually offer access to pre-release beta versions of Microsoft software.[[260]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-265)[[261]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-266) In April 2004, Microsoft launched a community site for developers and users, titled [Channel 9](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Channel_9_(Microsoft) "Channel 9 (Microsoft)"), that provides a [wiki](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wiki "Wiki") and an [Internet forum](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internet_forum "Internet forum").[[262]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-267) Another community site that provides daily [videocasts](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Podcast#Video_podcasts "Podcast") and other services, On10.net, launched on March 3, 2006.[[263]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-268) Free technical support is traditionally provided through online [Usenet](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usenet "Usenet") newsgroups, and [CompuServe](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CompuServe "CompuServe") in the past, monitored by Microsoft employees; there can be several newsgroups for a single product. Helpful people can be elected by peers or Microsoft employees for [Microsoft Most Valuable Professional](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft_Most_Valuable_Professional "Microsoft Most Valuable Professional") (MVP) status, which entitles them to a sort of special social status and possibilities for awards and other benefits.[[264]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-269)

Noted for its internal [lexicon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lexicon "Lexicon"), the expression "[eating your own dog food](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eating_your_own_dog_food "Eating your own dog food")" is used to describe the policy of using pre-release and beta versions of products inside Microsoft to test them in "real-world" situations.[[265]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-270) This is usually shortened to just "dog food" and is used as a noun, verb, and adjective. Another bit of [jargon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jargon "Jargon"), [FYIFV](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/FYIFV "FYIFV") or FYIV ("[Fuck](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fuck "Fuck") You, I'm [Fully] Vested"), is used by an employee to indicate they are [financially independent](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Financial_independence "Financial independence") and can avoid work anytime they wish.[[266]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-271)

Microsoft is an outspoken opponent of the cap on [H-1B visas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/H-1B_visa "H-1B visa"), which allows companies in the U.S. to employ certain foreign workers. Bill Gates claims the cap on H1B visas makes it difficult to hire employees for the company, stating "I'd certainly get rid of the H1B cap" in 2005.[[267]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-272) Critics of H1B visas argue that relaxing the limits would result in increased unemployment for U.S. citizens due to H1B workers working for lower salaries.[[268]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-273)

The [Human Rights Campaign](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_Rights_Campaign "Human Rights Campaign") Corporate Equality Index, a report of how progressive the organization deems company policies towards [LGBT](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LGBT "LGBT") employees, rated Microsoft as 87% from 2002 to 2004 and as 100% from 2005 to 2010 after they allowed gender expression.[[269]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-274)

In August 2018, Microsoft implemented a policy for all companies providing subcontractors to require 12 weeks of paid parental leave to each employee. This expands on the former requirement from 2015 requiring 15 days of paid vacation and sick leave each year.[[270]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-275) In 2015, Microsoft established its own parental leave policy to allow 12 weeks off for parental leave with an additional 8 weeks for the parent who gave birth.[[271]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-276)

### Environment

In 2011, [Greenpeace](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Greenpeace "Greenpeace") released a report rating the top ten big brands in [cloud computing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cloud_computing "Cloud computing") on their sources of electricity for their [data centers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Data_center "Data center"). At the time, data centers consumed up to 2% of all global electricity, and this amount was projected to increase. [Phil Radford](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phil_Radford "Phil Radford") of Greenpeace said, "We are concerned that this new explosion in electricity use could lock us into old, polluting energy sources instead of the clean energy available today",[[272]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-277) and called on "Amazon, Microsoft and other leaders of the information-technology industry must embrace clean energy to power their cloud-based data centers".[[273]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-278) In 2013, Microsoft agreed to buy power generated by a Texas wind project to power one of its data centers.[[274]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-279)

Microsoft is ranked on the 17th place in Greenpeace's _Guide to Greener Electronics_ (16th Edition) that ranks 18 electronics manufacturers according to their policies on toxic chemicals, recycling, and climate change.[[275]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-280) Microsoft's timeline for phasing out [brominated flame retardant](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brominated_flame_retardant "Brominated flame retardant") (BFRs) and [phthalates](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phthalate "Phthalate") in all products was 2012 but its commitment to phasing out [PVC](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Polyvinyl_chloride "Polyvinyl chloride") is not clear. As of January 2011,[[update]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Microsoft&action=edit) it has no products that are completely free from PVC and BFRs.[[276]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-281)[_[needs update](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual\_of\_Style/Dates\_and\_numbers#Chronological\_items "Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Dates and numbers")_]

Microsoft's main U.S. campus received a silver certification from the [Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leadership_in_Energy_and_Environmental_Design "Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design") (LEED) program in 2008, and it installed over 2,000 [solar panels](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Solar_panel "Solar panel") on top of its buildings at its [Silicon Valley](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Silicon_Valley "Silicon Valley") campus, generating approximately 15 percent of the total energy needed by the facilities in April 2005.[[277]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-news1-282) Microsoft makes use of alternative forms of transit. It created one of the world's largest private bus systems, the "Connector", to transport people from outside the company; for on-campus transportation, the "Shuttle Connect" uses a large fleet of hybrid cars to save fuel. The "Connector" does not compete with the public bus system and works with it to provide a cohesive transportation network not just for its employees but also for the public.[[278]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-283)

Microsoft also subsidizes regional [public transport](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Public_transport "Public transport"), provided by [Sound Transit](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sound_Transit "Sound Transit") and [King County Metro](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/King_County_Metro "King County Metro"), as an incentive.[[277]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-news1-282)[[279]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-284) In February 2010, however, Microsoft took a stance against adding additional public transport and [high-occupancy vehicle](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/High-occupancy_vehicle_lane "High-occupancy vehicle lane") (HOV) lanes to the [State Route 520](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Washington_State_Route_520 "Washington State Route 520") and [its floating bridge](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evergreen_Point_Floating_Bridge "Evergreen Point Floating Bridge") connecting Redmond to Seattle; the company did not want to delay the construction any further.[[280]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-285) Microsoft was ranked number 1 in the list of the World's Best Multinational Workplaces by the Great Place to Work Institute in 2011.[[281]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-286)

In January 2020, the company announced a strategy to take the company [carbon negative](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carbon_footprint "Carbon footprint") by 2030 and to [remove all carbon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carbon_dioxide_removal "Carbon dioxide removal") that it has emitted since its foundation in 1975.[[282]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-287)[[283]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-288)[[284]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-289) On October 9, 2020, Microsoft permanently allowed [remote work](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Remote_work "Remote work").[[285]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-290) In January 2021, the company announced on [Twitter](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Twitter "Twitter") to join the [Climate Neutral Data Centre Pact](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Climate_Neutral_Data_Centre_Pact "Climate Neutral Data Centre Pact"), which engages the cloud infrastructure and data centers industries to reach [carbon neutrality](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carbon_neutrality "Carbon neutrality") in Europe by 2030, and also disclosed an investment in [Climeworks](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Climeworks "Climeworks"), a [direct air capture](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Direct_air_capture "Direct air capture") company partnered with [Carbfix](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carbfix "Carbfix") for [carbon sequestration](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carbon_sequestration "Carbon sequestration").[[list 1]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-MicrosoftClimeworks-296) In the same year, it was awarded the EPA's Green Power Leadership Award, citing the company's [all-renewable energy use](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/100%25_renewable_energy "100% renewable energy") since 2014.[[291]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-297)

In September 2023, Microsoft announced that it purchased $200 million in [carbon credits to offset](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carbon_offsets_and_credits "Carbon offsets and credits") 315,000 metric tons of carbon dioxide over 10 years from Heirloom Carbon, a carbon removal company that mixes [calcium oxide](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Calcium_oxide "Calcium oxide") from heated crushed [limestone](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Limestone "Limestone") with [water](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Water "Water") to form [carbon hydroxide](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Orthocarbonic_acid "Orthocarbonic acid") to absorb carbon dioxide from the atmosphere to [mineralize](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mineralization_(soil_science) "Mineralization (soil science)") back into limestone while the released carbon dioxide is [stored underground](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carbon_capture_and_storage "Carbon capture and storage") or [injected into concrete](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Environmental_impact_of_concrete#Carbon_concrete "Environmental impact of concrete").[[292]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-298)[[293]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-299) Despite spending spent more than $760 million through its Climate Innovation Fund by June 2024 on sustainability projects—including purchases of more than 5 million metric tonnes of carbon dioxide removal with carbon offsets and more than 34 megawatts of renewable energy—Microsoft's [Scope 3 emissions](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carbon_accounting "Carbon accounting") had increased by 31% from the company's 2020 baseline, which caused the company's total emissions to rise by 29% in 2023.[[294]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-300)

In 2023 Microsoft consumed 24 TWh of electricity, more than countries such as Iceland, Ghana, the Dominican Republic, or Tunisia.[[295]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-301)

### Headquarters

[![Image 29](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/Building92microsoft.jpg/250px-Building92microsoft.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Building92microsoft.jpg)

Building 92, home to the Microsoft Visitor Center

The corporate headquarters, informally known as the [Microsoft Redmond campus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft_Redmond_campus "Microsoft Redmond campus"), is located at One Microsoft Way in Redmond, Washington. Microsoft initially moved onto the grounds of the campus on February 26, 1986, weeks before the company went public on March 13. The headquarters has since experienced multiple expansions since its establishment. It is estimated to encompass over 8 million ft 2 (750,000 m 2) of office space and 30,000–40,000 employees.[[296]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-302) Additional offices are located in [Bellevue](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bellevue,_Washington "Bellevue, Washington") and [Issaquah, Washington](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Issaquah,_Washington "Issaquah, Washington") (90,000 employees worldwide). The company is planning to upgrade its Mountain View, California, campus on a grand scale. The company has occupied this campus since 1981. In 2016, the company bought the 32-acre (13 ha) campus, with plans to renovate and expand it by 25%.[[297]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-303) Microsoft operates an East Coast headquarters in [Charlotte, North Carolina](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charlotte,_North_Carolina "Charlotte, North Carolina").[[298]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-304)

In April 2024, it was announced that Microsoft would be opening a state-of-the-art artificial intelligence 'hub' around Paddington in London, England. It was announced that the division would be led by Jordan Hoffman, who previously worked for [Deepmind](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Google_DeepMind "Google DeepMind") and [Inflection](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inflection_AI "Inflection AI").[[299]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-305)

### Logo

Microsoft adopted the so-called "_[Pac-Man](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pac-Man "Pac-Man")_ Logo", designed by Scott Baker, on February 26, 1987, with the concept being similar to [InFocus Corporation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/InFocus "InFocus") logo that was adapted a year earlier in 1986. Baker stated "The new logo, in [Helvetica](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Helvetica "Helvetica") italic typeface, has a slash between the _o_ and _s_ to emphasize the "soft" part of the name and convey motion and speed".[[304]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-310) Dave Norris ran an internal joke campaign to save the old logo, which was green, in all uppercase, and featured a fanciful letter _O_, nicknamed the _blibbet_, but it was discarded.[[305]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-311)

Microsoft's logo with the tagline "Your potential. Our passion."—below the main corporate name—is based on a slogan Microsoft used in 2008. In 2002, the company started using the logo in the United States and eventually started a television campaign with the slogan, changed from the previous tagline of _"[Where do you want to go today?](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Where\_do\_you\_want\_to\_go\_today%3F "Where do you want to go today?")"_[[306]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-wherego1-312)[[307]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-potentialpassion1-313)[[308]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-314) During the private MGX (Microsoft Global Exchange) conference in 2010, Microsoft unveiled the company's next tagline, _"Be What's Next."_[[309]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-315) They also had a slogan/tagline "Making it all make sense."[[310]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-316) The Microsoft _Pac-Man_ logo was used for 25 years, 5 months, and 28 days until August 23, 2012, being the longest enduring logo to be used by the company.

On August 23, 2012, Microsoft unveiled a new corporate logo at the opening of its 23rd Microsoft store in Boston, indicating the company's shift of focus from the classic style to the tile-centric modern interface, which it uses/will use on the Windows Phone platform, Xbox 360, Windows 8 and the upcoming Office Suites.[[311]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-317) The new logo also includes four squares with the colors of the then-current Windows logo which have been used to represent Microsoft's four major products: Windows (blue), Office (orange), Xbox (green) and Bing (yellow).[[312]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-318) The logo also resembles the opening of one of the commercials for [Windows 95](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Windows_95 "Windows 95").[[313]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-319)[[314]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-320)

### Philanthropy

In 2015, Microsoft Philanthropies, an internal charitable organization, was established to bring the benefits of technology and the digital revolution to areas and groups that lack them. The organisation's key areas of focus are: donating cloud computing resources to university researchers and nonprofit groups; supporting the expansion of broadband access worldwide; funding international computer science education through YouthSpark; supporting tech education in the U.S. from kindergarten to high school; and donating to global child and refugee relief organizations.[[317]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-323)[[318]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-324)

During the [COVID-19 pandemic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic "COVID-19 pandemic"), Microsoft's president, [Brad Smith](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brad_Smith_(American_lawyer) "Brad Smith (American lawyer)"), announced that an initial batch of supplies, including 15,000 protection goggles, [infrared thermometers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Infrared_thermometer "Infrared thermometer"), medical caps, and protective suits, was donated to Seattle, with further aid to come soon.[[319]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-325)

During the [Russian invasion of Ukraine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine "Russian invasion of Ukraine") Microsoft started monitoring [cyberattacks](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cyberattack "Cyberattack") originating from the [Government of Russia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Government_of_Russia "Government of Russia") and Russia-backed hackers. In June 2022, Microsoft published the report on Russian cyber attacks and concluded that state-backed Russian hackers "have engaged in "strategic espionage" against governments, [think tanks](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Think_tank "Think tank"), businesses and [aid groups](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aid_agency "Aid agency")" in 42 countries supporting [Kyiv](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kyiv "Kyiv").[[320]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-326)[[321]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-327)

Microsoft also supports initiatives through its AI for Accessibility grant program, providing funding to various global organizations that create technologies to enhance accessibility for individuals with disabilities. Among grant recipients from the Asia-Pacific region are Sri Lankan IT company Fortude, Thailand-based Vulcan Coalition, and Indonesian organization Kerjabilitas.[[322]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-328)

### Controversies

Main articles: [Microsoft litigation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft_litigation "Microsoft litigation") and [Criticism of Microsoft](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Criticism_of_Microsoft "Criticism of Microsoft")

Criticism of Microsoft has followed various aspects of its products and business practices. Frequently criticized are the [ease of use](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ease_of_use "Ease of use"), [robustness](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robustness_(computer_science) "Robustness (computer science)"), and [security](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computer_security "Computer security") of the company's software. They have also been criticized for the use of [permatemp](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Permatemp "Permatemp") employees (employees employed for years as "temporary", and therefore without medical benefits), the use of [forced retention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Forced_retention "Forced retention") tactics, which means that employees would be sued if they tried to leave.[[323]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-329) Historically, Microsoft has also been accused of overworking employees, in many cases, leading to [burnout](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Occupational_burnout "Occupational burnout") within just a few years of joining the company. The company is often referred to as a "Velvet Sweatshop", a term which originated in a 1989 _[Seattle Times](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle\_Times "Seattle Times")_ article,[[324]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-330) and later became used to describe the company by some of Microsoft's own employees.[[325]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-331) This characterization is derived from the perception that Microsoft provides nearly everything for its employees in a convenient place, but in turn overworks them to a point where it would be bad for their (possibly long-term) health.

As reported by several news outlets,[[326]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-332)[[327]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-Neate-333) an Irish subsidiary of Microsoft based in the [Republic of Ireland](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republic_of_Ireland "Republic of Ireland") declared £220 bn in profits but paid no corporation tax for the year 2020. This is due to the company being tax resident in [Bermuda](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bermuda "Bermuda") as mentioned in the accounts for 'Microsoft Round Island One, a subsidiary that collects license fees from the use of Microsoft software worldwide. Dame [Margaret Hodge](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Margaret_Hodge "Margaret Hodge"), a [Labour](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Labour_Party_(UK) "Labour Party (UK)")[MP](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Member_of_Parliament_(United_Kingdom) "Member of Parliament (United Kingdom)") in the UK said, "It is unsurprising – yet still shocking – that massively wealthy global corporations openly, unashamedly and blatantly refuse to pay tax on the profits they make in the countries where they undertake business".[[327]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-Neate-333)

In 2020, [ProPublica](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ProPublica "ProPublica") reported that the company had diverted more than $39 billion in U.S. profits to Puerto Rico using a mechanism structured to make it seem as if the company was unprofitable on paper. As a result, the company paid a tax rate on those profits of "nearly 0%". When the [Internal Revenue Service](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internal_Revenue_Service "Internal Revenue Service") audited these transactions, ProPublica reported that Microsoft aggressively fought back, including successfully lobbying Congress to change the law to make it harder for the agency to conduct audits of large corporations.[[328]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-334)[[329]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-335) In 2023, Microsoft reported in a securities filing that the U.S. [Internal Revenue Service](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internal_Revenue_Service "Internal Revenue Service") was alleging that the company owed the U.S. $28.9 billion in past taxes, plus penalties related to mis-allocation of corporate profits over a decade.[[330]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-336)

"Embrace, extend, and extinguish" (EEE),[[331]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-DeadlyEmbrace-337) also known as "embrace, extend, and exterminate,"[[332]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-338) is a phrase that the [U.S. Department of Justice](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Department_of_Justice "United States Department of Justice") found[[333]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-339) that was used internally by Microsoft[[334]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-340) to describe its strategy for entering product categories involving widely used standards, extending those standards with [proprietary](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Proprietary_software "Proprietary software") capabilities, and then using those differences to strongly disadvantage competitors. Microsoft is frequently accused of using anticompetitive tactics and abusing its monopolistic power. People who use their products and services often end up becoming dependent on them, a process is known as [vendor lock-in](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vendor_lock-in "Vendor lock-in").

Microsoft was the first company to participate in [the PRISM surveillance program](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PRISM_(surveillance_program) "PRISM (surveillance program)"), according to leaked NSA documents obtained by _The Guardian_[[335]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-341) and _The Washington Post_[[336]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-342) in June 2013, and acknowledged by government officials following the leak.[[337]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-343) The program authorizes the government to secretly access data of non-US citizens hosted by American companies without a warrant. Microsoft has denied participation in such a program.[[338]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-344)

[Jesse Jackson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jesse_Jackson "Jesse Jackson") believes Microsoft should hire more [minorities](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Minorities "Minorities") and women. In 2015, he praised Microsoft for appointing two women to its board of directors.[[339]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-345)

In 2020, [Salesforce](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Salesforce "Salesforce"), the manufacturer of the [Slack](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Slack_(software) "Slack (software)") platform, complained to European regulators about Microsoft due to the integration of the Teams service into Office 365. Negotiations with the European Commission continued until the summer of 2023, but, as it became known to the media, they reached an impasse. Microsoft is now facing an antitrust investigation.[[340]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-346)

In June 2024, Microsoft Corp. faced a potential EU fine after regulators accused it of abusing market power by bundling its Teams video-conferencing app with its Office 365 and Microsoft 365 software. The European Commission issued a statement of objections, alleging Microsoft's practice since 2019 gave Teams an unfair market advantage and limited interoperability with competing software. Despite Microsoft's efforts to avoid deeper scrutiny, including unbundling Teams, regulators remained unconvinced. This action followed a 2019 complaint from Slack, which was later acquired by Salesforce. Microsoft's Teams usage soared during the pandemic, growing from 2 million daily users in 2017 to 300 million in 2023. The company has a history of antitrust battles in the U.S. and Europe, with over €2 billion in EU fines previously imposed for similar abuses.[[341]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-347)

In October 2024, Microsoft fired two employees, software engineers Ibtihal Aboussad and Vaniya Agrawal,[[342]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-348) who organized an unauthorized vigil at its Redmond headquarters to honor Palestinians killed in the [Gaza war](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gaza_war "Gaza war"). The employees, part of the group "No Azure for Apartheid," sought to address the company's involvement in the Israeli government's use of its technology.[[343]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-349) On 20 March 2025, before an event at Seattle's Great Hall with Brad Smith and Steve Ballmer, protestors projected "Microsoft powers [genocide](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gaza_genocide "Gaza genocide")" on the wall. Subsequently, two employees interrupted AI executive Mustafa Suleyman at a speaking event on 4 April 2025 in protest at the company's support of Israel.[[344]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-350) The [Boycott, Divestment and Sanctions](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boycott,_Divestment_and_Sanctions "Boycott, Divestment and Sanctions") movement added Microsoft to its list of targets for partnering "with the apartheid regime of Israel and its prison system".[[345]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-351)In February 2025, the Associated Press reported that the Israeli military was utilizing Microsoft-developed artificial intelligence tools in its military and intelligence operations against the people of Gaza. In May 2025, Microsoft issued an unsigned statement confirming that these services had been made available to Israel. However, no evidence has yet been found to indicate that these tools were employed during the massacre of the people of Gaza.[[346]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-352)

In November 2024, the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) launched an investigation into Microsoft, focusing on potential antitrust violations related to its cloud computing, AI, and cybersecurity businesses. The probe scrutinized Microsoft's bundling of cloud services with products like Office and security tools, as well as its growing AI presence through its partnership with OpenAI. This inquiry is part of broader efforts by the U.S. government to curb the power of major tech companies, especially under FTC chair Lina Khan. Concerns were raised about Microsoft's licensing practices potentially locking customers into its services and its AI investments possibly sidestepping regulatory oversight.[[347]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-353)

In June 2025 Microsoft recently helped suspend the email account of an International Criminal Court prosecutor in the Netherlands who was investigating Israel for war crimes in order to comply with a Trump executive order.[[348]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-354)[[349]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft#cite_note-355)

results.content:
Microsoft Corporation is an American multinational technology company that has been a key player in the computer industry since its founding in 1975. Headquartered in Redmond, Washington, Microsoft initially gained dominance in the operating systems market during the 1980s and ’90s with MS-DOS and Windows. Its strong market position eventually gave rise to the company’s diverse and extensive range of technological offerings, from personal computing and entertainment to enterprise cloud [...] Microsoft operates research labs in Cambridge, England (1997); Beijing (1998); Bengaluru, India (2005); Cambridge, Massachusetts (2008); New York, New York (2012); and Montreal (2015). Microsoft’s operations can be divided into three major business segments: productivity and business processes, intelligent cloud, and more personal computing. Each segment consists of several products and services.

## Productivity and business processes [...] By the mid-1990s Microsoft, which became a publicly owned corporation in 1986, had become one of the most powerful brands and profitable companies in American history. It consistently earned profits of 25 cents on every sales dollar, an astonishing record. Microsoft Corporation is an American multinational technology company that has been a key player in the [computer](/technology/computer) industry since its founding in 1975. Headquartered in [Redmond](/place/Redmond-Washington), Washington, Microsoft initially gained dominance in the [operating systems](/technology/operating-system) market during the 1980s and ’90s with MS-DOS and [Windows](/technology/Microsoft-Windows). Its strong market position eventually gave rise to the company’s diverse and extensive range of technological offerings, from [personal computing](/technology/personal-computer) and entertainment to [enterprise](/money/business-organization) [cloud computing](/technology/cloud-computing) and [artificial intelligence](/technology/artificial-intelligence).

Microsoft operates research labs in Cambridge, England (1997); Beijing (1998); Bengaluru, India (2005); Cambridge, Massachusetts (2008); [New York](/place/New-York-state), New York (2012); and Montreal (2015). Microsoft’s operations can be divided into three major business segments: productivity and business processes, intelligent cloud, and more personal computing. Each segment consists of several products and services.

## Productivity and business processes

**Microsoft Office Suite** includes the mainstay [Word](/technology/Microsoft-Word), [Excel](/technology/Microsoft-Excel), and [PowerPoint](/technology/Microsoft-PowerPoint) applications and can be further divided into commercial and consumer categories:

![Technician operates the system console on the new UNIVAC 1100/83 computer at the Fleet Analysis Center, Corona Annex, Naval Weapons Station, Seal Beach, CA. June 1, 1981. Univac magnetic tape drivers or readers in background. Universal Automatic Computer](https://cdn.britannica.com/93/149293-131-2CD523EA/Technician-computer-system-console-UNIVAC-Corona-Annex-June-1-1981.jpg)

**[LinkedIn](/money/LinkedIn)** is a business-oriented [social media](/topic/social-media) platform with services including Talent Solutions, Marketing Solutions, Premium Subscriptions, and Sales Solutions.

**Microsoft Dynamics** is a suite of intelligent and cloud-based applications designed to assist in various business operations, including finance, marketing, sales, [supply chain management](/money/what-is-supply-chain-management), and customer service.

## Intelligent cloud

**Azure Cloud Services** is Microsoft’s flagship cloud computing platform; it offers hundreds of cloud-based products and services. The second-largest cloud service in the world, Azure held roughly 23 percent of global market [share](/money/stock-finance) for the cloud in 2023, second only to [Amazon Web Services](/money/Amazoncom#ref371214) (AWS).

Other intelligent cloud services include [SQL](/technology/SQL) Server, Windows Server, Visual Studio, System Center, and [GitHub](/technology/GitHub).

## **What do you think?**

**Explore the ProCon debate**

## More personal computing

**[Windows](/technology/Microsoft-Windows) Operating System** has gradually become a cornerstone of Microsoft’s success since its launch in the 1980s.

**[Xbox](/technology/Xbox) gaming console** and various gaming subscriptions, such as Xbox Game Pass, have positioned Microsoft as a formidable player in the gaming industry.

**Surface devices** are Microsoft’s touchscreen-based hardware, including laptops, tablets, and interactive whiteboards. Other products in this category include HoloLens and other PC accessories.

## Founding and early growth

In 1975 [Bill Gates](/money/Bill-Gates) and [Paul G. Allen](/money/Paul-Allen), two boyhood friends from [Seattle](/place/Seattle-Washington), converted [BASIC](/technology/BASIC), a popular mainframe [computer programming language](/technology/computer-programming-language), for use on an early [personal computer](/technology/personal-computer) (PC), the Altair. Shortly afterward, Gates and Allen founded Microsoft, deriving the name from the words *microcomputer* and *software*. During the next few years, they refined BASIC and developed other [programming languages](/technology/computer-programming-language).

![IBM Personal Computer](https://cdn.britannica.com/08/23608-004-47D6DC21/IBM-Personal-Computer-machine-Microsoft-MS-DOS-operating-1981.jpg?w=385)

**The world runs on DOS.** In 1980, [International Business Machines Corporation](/money/International-Business-Machines-Corporation) (IBM) asked Microsoft to produce the essential [software](/technology/software), or [operating system](/technology/operating-system), for its first [personal computer](/technology/personal-computer), the IBM PC. Microsoft purchased an operating system from another company, modified it, and renamed it [MS-DOS](/technology/MS-DOS) (Microsoft Disk Operating System). MS-DOS was released with the IBM PC in 1981. Thereafter, most manufacturers of personal computers licensed MS-DOS as their operating system, generating vast revenues for Microsoft; by the early 1990s, it had sold more than 100 million copies of the program and defeated rival operating systems such as CP/M, which it displaced in the early 1980s, and later [IBM OS/2](/technology/IBM-OS-2).

**The Windows revolution.** Microsoft deepened its position in operating systems with [Windows](/technology/Microsoft-Windows), a [graphical user interface](/technology/graphical-user-interface) whose third version, released in 1990, gained a wide following. By 1993, Windows 3.0 and its subsequent versions were selling at a rate of one million copies per month, and nearly 90 percent of the world’s PCs ran on a Microsoft operating system. In 1995 the company released Windows 95, which for the first time fully integrated MS-DOS with Windows and effectively matched in ease of use [Apple Computer](/money/Apple-Inc)’s [Mac OS](/technology/macOS).

**Powering the office.** Microsoft also became the leader in productivity software such as [word processing](/technology/word-processing) and [spreadsheet](/technology/spreadsheet) programs, outdistancing longtime rivals Lotus and WordPerfect in the process.

**Entering the media world.** Microsoft dramatically expanded its electronic publishing division, created in 1985 and already notable for the success of its multimedia encyclopedia, *[Encarta](/topic/Encarta)*. It also entered the information services and entertainment industries with a wide range of products and services, most notably the Microsoft Network and [MSNBC](/money/MSNBC) (a [joint venture](/money/joint-venture) with the [National Broadcasting Company](/money/National-Broadcasting-Co-Inc), a major American television network, which began in 1995 and ended in 2012).

## The price of success: Regulatory scrutiny

By the mid-1990s Microsoft, which [became a publicly owned corporation](/money/ipo-initial-public-offering) in 1986, had become one of the most powerful [brands](/money/brand) and [profitable](/money/earnings-per-share-quarterly-earnings) companies in American history. It consistently earned profits of 25 cents on every sales dollar, an astonishing record. In the company’s 1996 [fiscal year](/money/fiscal-year), it topped $2 billion in [net income](/money/profit) for the first time, and its unbroken string of profits continued, even during the [Great Recession](/money/great-recession) of 2007–09 (its net income had grown to more than $14 billion by fiscal year 2009).

Its rapid growth in a fiercely competitive and fast-changing industry, however, spawned resentment and jealousy among rivals, some of whom complained that the company’s practices violated U.S. laws against unfair competition. Microsoft and its defenders countered that, far from stifling competition and technical innovation, its rise had encouraged both and that its software had consistently become less expensive and more useful. A [U.S. Justice Department](/topic/US-Department-of-Justice) investigation concluded in 1994 with a settlement in which Microsoft changed some sales practices that the government contended enabled the company to unfairly discourage Windows customers from trying alternative programs. The following year the Justice Department successfully challenged Microsoft’s proposed purchase of [Intuit Inc.](/money/Intuit-Inc), then the leading maker of financial software for PCs.

## Chasing the Internet and a return of regulatory woes

Partly because of its stunning success in PC software, Microsoft was slow to realize the commercial possibilities of network systems and the [Internet](/technology/Internet). In 1993 it released Windows NT, a landmark program that tied disparate PCs together and offered improved reliability and network security. Sales were initially disappointing, but by 1996 Windows NT was being hailed as the likely standard for PC networking, quickly surpassing Novell’s NetWare in market share.

Microsoft did not move into Internet software until a new venture, [Netscape Communications Corp.](/money/Netscape-Communications-Corp), had introduced Navigator, a Web [browser](/technology/browser) that simplified the once-arcane process of navigating the [World Wide Web](/topic/World-Wide-Web). In a violent change of course, Microsoft quickly developed its own browser, [Internet Explorer](/technology/Internet-Explorer), made it free, and moved aggressively to persuade computer makers and Internet service providers to distribute it exclusively. By 1996 Microsoft was bundling Explorer with Windows OS and had begun the process of integrating Explorer directly into Windows. In response, Netscape accused Microsoft of violating its 1995 consent decree and sued; those efforts helped to persuade the Justice Department to reopen a broad investigation of Microsoft.

In 1999, following a trial that lasted 30 months, a judge found Microsoft in violation of the [Sherman Antitrust Act](/event/Sherman-Antitrust-Act) (1890) and ordered the breakup of the company. In 2001 an appeals court overturned the breakup order but still found the company guilty of illegally trying to maintain a [monopoly](/money/monopoly-economics). The company’s legal woes continued in 2004: The [European Union](/topic/European-Union) (EU) levied the largest fine in the organization’s history to that point, €497.2 million ($611 million), in retaliation for what were described as Microsoft’s near-monopoly practices. In February 2008 the EU imposed an even higher fine, €899 million ($1.35 billion), on the company for having defied the EU’s 2004 antitrust decision against Microsoft for illegally bundling multimedia software with its Windows operating system to the exclusion of competitors.

## Entry into the gaming and mobile phone markets

In 2001 Microsoft released the [Xbox](/technology/Xbox), an [electronic game](/topic/electronic-game) console that quickly captured second place in the video gaming market. In 2002 it launched [Xbox Live](/topic/Xbox-Live), a broadband gaming network for its consoles. A more powerful gaming console, the [Xbox 360](/technology/Xbox-360), was released in 2005. In an intensely competitive market, where the Xbox faced strong pressure from the [Nintendo Wii](/topic/Nintendo-Wii) and [Sony](/money/Sony) [PlayStation](/topic/PlayStation), Microsoft struggled through the years to make consistent profits from its console. For example, in 2009 the company cut the price of the Xbox 360 Elite by as much as 25 percent in order to pick up market share. The move was successful; by 2010 the Xbox 360 was the most-used game console in the American home. But at the same time, the price cuts also led to a 6 percent drop in revenue in Microsoft’s Entertainment and Devices Division (EDD). The Xbox 360 was succeeded in 2013 by the Xbox One, which in turn was replaced by Xbox Series [X](/money/Twitter) and Xbox Series S in 2020.

![Xbox 360 at the Tokyo Game Show](https://cdn.britannica.com/59/90459-050-2293BA10/Microsoft-video-game-machine-demonstration-units-Xbox-2005.jpg?w=385)

Other EDD products also struggled. The Zune family of portable media players introduced in 2006 failed to challenge the market dominance of Apple’s [iPod](/technology/iPod), and it was discontinued in 2011. The Windows Mobile OS, used in [smartphones](/technology/smartphone) made by a variety of vendors, including HTC, LG, [Motorola](/money/Motorola-Inc), and [Samsung](/money/Samsung-Electronics), trailed in market share in the [United States](/place/United-States) behind Research in Motion’s [BlackBerry](/technology/BlackBerry-wireless-device) and Apple’s [iPhone](/technology/iPhone). In 2009 Microsoft ceased publishing online and disc versions of its *[Encarta](/topic/Encarta)* encyclopedia.

[Microsoft](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft "Microsoft") is a multinational computer technology corporation. Microsoft was founded on April 4, 1975, by [Bill Gates](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bill_Gates "Bill Gates") and [Paul Allen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paul_Allen "Paul Allen") in [Albuquerque, New Mexico](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Albuquerque,_New_Mexico "Albuquerque, New Mexico").[[1]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_Microsoft#cite_note-founding-1) Its current best-selling products are the [Microsoft Windows](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft_Windows "Microsoft Windows")[operating system](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Operating_system "Operating system"); [Microsoft Office](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft_Office "Microsoft Office"), a suite of productivity software; [Xbox](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xbox "Xbox"), a line of entertainment of games, music, and video; [Bing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bing_(search_engine) "Bing (search engine)"), a line of search engines; and [Microsoft Azure](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft_Azure "Microsoft Azure"), a cloud services platform.[[2]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_Microsoft#cite_note-MSFT-20190130-2)

In 1980, Microsoft formed a partnership with [IBM](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IBM "IBM") to bundle Microsoft's operating system with IBM computers; with that deal, IBM paid Microsoft a royalty for every sale. In 1985, IBM requested Microsoft to develop a new operating system for their computers called [OS/2](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/OS/2 "OS/2"). Microsoft produced that operating system, but also continued to sell their own alternative, which proved to be in direct competition with OS/2. Microsoft Windows eventually overshadowed OS/2 in terms of sales. When Microsoft launched several versions of Microsoft Windows in the 1990s, they had captured over 90% market share of the world's personal computers.

As of June 30, 2015, Microsoft has a global annual revenue of US$86.83 billion (~$109 billion in 2023) and 128,076 employees worldwide.[[3]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_Microsoft#cite_note-2014Revenue-3) It develops, manufactures, licenses, and supports a wide range of [software](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computer_software "Computer software") products for computing devices.[[4]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_Microsoft#cite_note-2005annual-4)[[5]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_Microsoft#cite_note-fastfacts-5)[[6]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_Microsoft#cite_note-2007financials-6)

1975–1985: The founding of Microsoft
------------------------------------

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=History_of_Microsoft&action=edit&section=1 "Edit section: 1975–1985: The founding of Microsoft")]

[![Image 7](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9b/Altair_8800_and_Model_33_ASR_Teletype.jpg/250px-Altair_8800_and_Model_33_ASR_Teletype.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Altair_8800_and_Model_33_ASR_Teletype.jpg)

[Altair 8800](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Altair_8800 "Altair 8800") computer with the popular Model 33 ASR Teletype as terminal, paper tape reader, and paper tape punch.

In late 1974, [Paul Allen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paul_Allen "Paul Allen"), a programmer at [Honeywell](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Honeywell "Honeywell"), was walking through [Harvard Square](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harvard_Square "Harvard Square") when he saw the cover of the January 1975 issue of _[Popular Electronics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Popular\_Electronics "Popular Electronics")_ that demonstrated the [Altair 8800](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Altair_8800 "Altair 8800"), the first [microcomputer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microcomputer "Microcomputer").[[7]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_Microsoft#cite_note-keyevents-7)[[8]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_Microsoft#cite_note-leibovich20001231-8) Allen bought the magazine and rushed to [Currier House](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Currier_House_(Harvard_College) "Currier House (Harvard College)") at [Harvard College](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harvard_College "Harvard College"), where he showed it to high school friend [Bill Gates](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bill_Gates "Bill Gates").[[8]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_Microsoft#cite_note-leibovich20001231-8) They saw potential to develop an implementation of [BASIC](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BASIC "BASIC") for the system.[[9]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_Microsoft#cite_note-9)

Gates called Altair manufacturer [Micro Instrumentation and Telemetry Systems](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Micro_Instrumentation_and_Telemetry_Systems "Micro Instrumentation and Telemetry Systems") (MITS), offering to demonstrate the implementation. Allen and Gates had neither an interpreter nor an Altair system, yet in the eight weeks before the demo, they developed an interpreter with the help of [Monte Davidoff](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Monte_Davidoff "Monte Davidoff"). When Allen flew to [Albuquerque](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Albuquerque,_New_Mexico "Albuquerque, New Mexico") to meet with MITS, the interpreter worked and MITS agreed to distribute [Altair BASIC](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Altair_BASIC "Altair BASIC").[[10]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_Microsoft#cite_note-thocp1-10)[[8]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_Microsoft#cite_note-leibovich20001231-8) Allen moved to Albuquerque, Gates soon quit Harvard to join him, and they co-founded Microsoft there.[[8]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_Microsoft#cite_note-leibovich20001231-8) Revenues of the company totalled $16,005 by the end of 1976.

[![Image 8](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/5/5e/Microsoft-Staff-1978.jpg/250px-Microsoft-Staff-1978.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Microsoft-Staff-1978.jpg)

Middle: [Bob O'Rear](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bob_O%27Rear "Bob O'Rear"), [Bob Greenberg](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Bob_Greenberg_(programmer)&action=edit&redlink=1 "Bob Greenberg (programmer) (page does not exist)"), [Marc McDonald](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marc_McDonald "Marc McDonald"), [Gordon Letwin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gordon_Letwin "Gordon Letwin")

Bottom: [Bill Gates](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bill_Gates "Bill Gates"), Andrea Lewis, [Marla Wood](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Marla_Wood&action=edit&redlink=1 "Marla Wood (page does not exist)"), [Paul Allen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paul_Allen "Paul Allen")

Not pictured: [Ric Weiland](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ric_Weiland "Ric Weiland"), [Miriam Lubow](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Miriam_Lubow&action=edit&redlink=1 "Miriam Lubow (page does not exist)")[[11]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_Microsoft#cite_note-Allen2011-11)

Allen came up with the original name of _Micro-Soft_, a [portmanteau](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Portmanteau "Portmanteau") of [microcomputer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microcomputer "Microcomputer") and [software](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Software "Software").[[12]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_Microsoft#cite_note-12) Hyphenated in its early incarnations, on November 26, 1976, the company was registered under that name with the Secretary of State of New Mexico. The first employee Gates and Allen hired was their high school collaborator [Ric Weiland](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ric_Weiland "Ric Weiland").[[10]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_Microsoft#cite_note-thocp1-10) The company's first international office was founded on November 1, 1978, in Japan, entitled "[ASCII](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ASCII_(company) "ASCII (company)") Microsoft" (now called "[Microsoft Japan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft_Japan "Microsoft Japan")"), and on November 29, 1979, the term, "Microsoft" was first used by Bill Gates.[[7]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_Microsoft#cite_note-keyevents-7) On January 1, 1979, the company moved from Albuquerque to a new home in [Bellevue, Washington](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bellevue,_Washington "Bellevue, Washington"),[[7]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_Microsoft#cite_note-keyevents-7) since it was hard to recruit top programmers to Albuquerque. Shortly before the move, 11 of the then-13 employees posed for the staff photo on the right.[[13]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_Microsoft#cite_note-13)

[Steve Ballmer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Steve_Ballmer "Steve Ballmer") joined the company on June 11, 1980, and would later succeed Bill Gates as CEO[[7]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_Microsoft#cite_note-keyevents-7) from January 2000 until February 2014. The company restructured on June 25, 1981, to become an incorporated business in its home state of Washington (with a further change of its name to "Microsoft Corporation, Inc."). As part of the restructuring, Bill Gates became president of the company and chairman of the board, and Paul Allen became executive vice president and vice chairman.[[7]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_Microsoft#cite_note-keyevents-7) In 1983, Allen left the company after receiving a [Hodgkin lymphoma](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hodgkin_lymphoma "Hodgkin lymphoma") diagnosis, though he remained on the board as vice-chairman. This effectively ended the formal business partnership between Gates and Allen, which had been strained months prior due to a contentious dispute over Microsoft equity.[[14]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_Microsoft#cite_note-before_microsoft-14) Later in the decade, Gates and Allen repaired their relationship and together the two donated millions to their childhood school [Lakeside](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lakeside_School_(Seattle) "Lakeside School (Seattle)").[[8]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_Microsoft#cite_note-leibovich20001231-8) They remained friends until Allen's death in October 2018.[[15]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_Microsoft#cite_note-Gates_Mourns_Allen-15)

Microsoft's early products were different variants of [Microsoft BASIC](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft_BASIC "Microsoft BASIC") which was the dominant programming language in late 1970s and early 1980s home computers such as [Apple II](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Apple_II "Apple II") ([Applesoft BASIC](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Applesoft_BASIC "Applesoft BASIC")) and [Commodore 64](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commodore_64 "Commodore 64") ([Commodore BASIC](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commodore_BASIC "Commodore BASIC")), and were also provided with early versions of the [IBM PC](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IBM_PC "IBM PC") as the [IBM Cassette BASIC](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IBM_Cassette_BASIC "IBM Cassette BASIC").

Microsoft also marketed through an Apple dealer in West Palm Beach, Florida two products for the Radio-Shack TRS-80. One was "Typing Tutor" which led the user through learning to use a keyboard. The other was authored by a professor at the University of Hawaii called "MuMATH" and had the ability to do mathematics in long integer math to avoid floating point numbers.

[![Image 9](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/61/Microsoft_Softcard_Z80_coprocessor_for_Apple_II.jpg/250px-Microsoft_Softcard_Z80_coprocessor_for_Apple_II.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Microsoft_Softcard_Z80_coprocessor_for_Apple_II.jpg)

The [Z-80 SoftCard](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Z-80_SoftCard "Z-80 SoftCard"), released in 1980

The first hardware product[[16]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_Microsoft#cite_note-lock19800506-16) was the [Z-80 SoftCard](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Z-80_SoftCard "Z-80 SoftCard") which enabled the Apple II to run the [CP/M](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CP/M "CP/M")[operating system](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Operating_system "Operating system"), at the time an industry-standard operating system for running business software and many [compilers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Compiler "Compiler") and [interpreters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interpreter_(computing) "Interpreter (computing)") for several [high-level languages](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/High-level_language "High-level language") on [microcomputers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microcomputer "Microcomputer"). The SoftCard was first demonstrated publicly at the [West Coast Computer Faire](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/West_Coast_Computer_Faire "West Coast Computer Faire") in March 1980.[[17]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_Microsoft#cite_note-Infoworld_Apr_1980-17)[[18]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_Microsoft#cite_note-Infoworld_Nov_1980-18) It was an immediate success; 5,000 cards, a large number given the microcomputer market at the time, were purchased in the initial three months at $349 (~$1,084 in 2023) each and it was Microsoft's number one revenue source in 1980.[[19]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_Microsoft#cite_note-19)

The first operating system publicly released by the company was a variant of [Unix](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unix "Unix") announced on August 25, 1980. Acquired from [AT&T](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AT%26T "AT&T") through a distribution license, Microsoft dubbed it [Xenix](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xenix "Xenix"), and hired [Santa Cruz Operation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Santa_Cruz_Operation "Santa Cruz Operation") in order to port/adapt the operating system to several platforms.[[20]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_Microsoft#cite_note-xenix1-20)[[21]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_Microsoft#cite_note-21) This Unix variant would become home to the first version of Microsoft's [word processor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Word_processor "Word processor"), [Microsoft Word](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft_Office_Word "Microsoft Office Word"). Originally titled "Multi-Tool Word", Microsoft Word became notable for its use of "What You See Is What You Get", or [WYSIWYG](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WYSIWYG "WYSIWYG") pioneered by the [Xerox Alto](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xerox_Alto "Xerox Alto") and the [Bravo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bravo_(software) "Bravo (software)") text editor in the 1970s.[[22]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_Microsoft#cite_note-22)[[23]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_Microsoft#cite_note-23)

Skeptics questioned the system software vendor's decision to produce application software. Gates said that doing so was not what _InfoWorld_ phrased as a "big-time operation", but Microsoft spent aggressively, with a reportedly "unlimited" R&D budget despite others in the industry advising against overexpansion.[[24]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_Microsoft#cite_note-caruso19840402-24) Word was first released in the spring of 1983, and free demonstration copies of the application were bundled with the November 1983 issue of [PC World](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PC_World "PC World"), making it one of the first programs to be distributed on-disk with a magazine. (Earlier magazine on-disk distributions included Robert Uiterwyk's BASIC in the May 1977 issue of Information Age.)[[25]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_Microsoft#cite_note-SWTPC-Uiterwyk-25)[[26]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_Microsoft#cite_note-RoyAllen-26) However, Xenix was never sold to end users directly although it was licensed to many software [OEMs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Original_equipment_manufacturer "Original equipment manufacturer") for resale. It grew to become the most popular version of Unix, measured by the number of machines running it[[27]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_Microsoft#cite_note-27) (note that Unix is a multi-user operating system, allowing simultaneous access to a machine by several users). By the mid-1980s Microsoft had gotten out of the Unix business, except for its ownership stake in [SCO](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/OpenServer "OpenServer").[[20]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_Microsoft#cite_note-xenix1-20)

[![Image 10](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f9/PC_DOS_1.10_screenshot.png/250px-PC_DOS_1.10_screenshot.png)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:PC_DOS_1.10_screenshot.png)

A typical [PC DOS](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IBM_PC_DOS "IBM PC DOS")[command line](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Command-line_interface "Command-line interface")

[IBM](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IBM "IBM") first approached Gates and Allen about Microsoft's upcoming [IBM Personal Computer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IBM_Personal_Computer "IBM Personal Computer") (IBM PC) in July 1980, shortly after Gates's mother began working on [United Way's](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_Way "United Way") executive board with IBM CEO [John Opel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Opel "John Opel").[[26]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_Microsoft#cite_note-RoyAllen-26)[[28]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_Microsoft#cite_note-bunnell1982febmar-28) On August 12, 1981, after negotiations with [Digital Research](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Digital_Research "Digital Research") failed, IBM awarded a contract to Microsoft to provide a version of the [CP/M](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CP/M "CP/M") operating system, which was set to be used in the IBM PC. For this deal, Microsoft purchased a [CP/M](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CP/M "CP/M") clone called [86-DOS](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/86-DOS "86-DOS") from [Tim Paterson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tim_Paterson "Tim Paterson") of [Seattle Computer Products](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle_Computer_Products "Seattle Computer Products") for less than US$100,000, which IBM renamed to [IBM PC DOS](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IBM_PC_DOS "IBM PC DOS"). The original CP/M was made by [Gary Kildall](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gary_Kildall "Gary Kildall") of [Digital Research](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Digital_Research "Digital Research"), Inc. Due to potential [copyright infringement](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Copyright_infringement "Copyright infringement") problems with CP/M, IBM marketed both CP/M and PC DOS for US$240 and US$40, respectively, with PC DOS eventually becoming the standard because of its lower price.[[29]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_Microsoft#cite_note-29)[[30]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_Microsoft#cite_note-30) Thirty-five of the company's 100 employees worked on the IBM project for more than a year. When the IBM PC debuted, Microsoft was the only company that offered operating system, programming language, and application software for the new computer.[[28]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_Microsoft#cite_note-bunnell1982febmar-28)

_InfoWorld_ stated in 1984 that Microsoft, with $55 million (~$137 million in 2023) in 1983 sales,[[24]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_Microsoft#cite_note-caruso19840402-24)

> is widely recognized as the most influential company in the microcomputer-software industry.
